author: {'steamid': '76561198322560368', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1588337029}
review:
It's a title inspired from symbian OS java game STRANDED with overall same concept but, enhanced Graphics, new features/systems.

There are minor bugs, execpt that it's nice to relive the memories of stranded on pc.
As the dev stated second version of game is coming out, i'm more excited to explore it.

Dynamic weather system is plus point, but the transition between TOD and weather condition is slightly faster than required as enthusiast users are going to play the game for looooonnnnnnggg time.
Audio is really nice as weather elements are nicely placed and it is somewhat realistic.

[b] There is one major issue about the video resources this title used despite the small draw radius. The GPU usage is always at 100%. On my laptop with an old GT GPU where I've played games which require huge draw distances like Euro Truck Sim 2, ARMA 3 it never went till 100%. [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198040972691', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 4308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1796, 'last_played': 1566358736}
review:
For informational purposes:

1. The game is really slow paced. Crafting feels like you're downloading a 1 GB file with a 100 kb/s download speed. It's not actually that bad, but it feels that way sometimes. The same goes for cooking and trying to level up, it takes a while.

2. You don't have access to all the craft items from the start, you have to unlock them by leveling up.

3. You level up only by doing quests, which are mostly crafting items and some kill quests here and there. The requirements are usually ridiculous, crafting many things to craft into a bigger thing. You can imagine that takes forever.

For multiplayer:

1. Once the lobby is created and the game starts, no one else can join in until you restart the lobby. The max players that can join is 4.

2. Players must stay close together if they want to explore the map, an invisible wall will stop any player that goes too far from the rest. 

3. There are a lot of loading screens when exploring the map. These loading screens are not a problem on single player, but when it's multiplayer... it can take very long depending on the other player(s)'s download speed. And I mean, VERY long. And it's not a one-time only thing, it will keep happening on the same part of the map.

4. All achievements go to the host ONLY. There's a workaround which involves saving the file and backing up the world BEFORE getting the achievement, and then sharing it with your friend(s). 

That should be enough reason to not recommend this game, right? Well, not really, at least for me. It's actually a really enjoyable game for the price. And even better on sale. To me, it's all about the feeling of progression, and IMO, this game has that. While I don't really like how the quest requirements are, for the most part, completely absurd; it gives you a great incentive to keep playing. It's a good, cheap survival game with many faults, but if you can ignore these, you'll likely enjoy this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198306142266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1208, 'last_played': 1565512713}
review:
this game has some good concepts. i like how when your health decreases the screen gets more fuzzy.
as a game still in developement, there isnt much to do in it, but to die allot. lol
what i dont like, is how fast enemies can run and how slow it takes to swing a weapon in the time frame for them to run away, its a bit silly. also that they keep being able to run away when they are super low on health, causing you a wasted effort, no xp given for this, because its based on crafted items availability and resources per leveling up.
would be great if they couldnt just destroy your builds/craftables in a mere 10 seconds. or invade your camp while your still on level 3... its happened twice to me. i gave up trying after this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198245135596', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1586648095}
review:
It's a fun little game that I actually really enjoy the gameplay of, it's unique and the only thing I dislike is how the camera/POV works. Outside of that, I think it's enjoyable as long as you typically enjoy fairly casual survival/sandbox/farming games.

As with most games, it's 100% better if you play multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027623403', 'num_games_owned': 660, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1565423193}
review: I'm pretty disappointed. Despite the reviews, I couldn't resist the price of the game being 90% off, and I bought it. Changing the resolution (I prefer playing window mode) I had to restart the game, and change the settings again. Now, I can't start a new game, so I'm refunding it despite getting it for really cheap. I can't recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166657180', 'num_games_owned': 267, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5285, 'last_played': 1561776968}
review: Adquiri este juego como muchos otros cuando estaba en descuento y tuve un poco mis dudas en el momento, pero algo me decia que valia la pena intentar. Y efectivamente el juego a pesar de parecer algo aburrido y sin chiste a primera instancia es bueno, ya que te da un mundo amplio para explorar y algunas criaturas interesantes (Que me encantaria se hubieran podido atrapar) ademas de una cantidad decente de articulos para construir y decorar. Ciertamente la historia por asi llamarla carece un poco de emocion, pero aun con eso me gusto bastante.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982950877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3146, 'last_played': 1697764159}
review:
I have to say it is a grinding game with no boost. I recently reinstalled this game and now I'm stuck at lvl 6 waiting for 30 more coin peaces. I do remember having fences in the game, right now I have 6 or so animals just floating at the beach.  It seems they too want to drown in the ocean.

lets get to the grit of it
Pros 
- Its a slow pace game where you might not get epilepsy.
- The start of the game is like every start. beach surrounded by trees where you are in the bubble of safety.
- You learn how to dig with a stick. (it looks like a high moon dance.)
- And very minimal survival skills needed. (I wouldn't say I would trust my life with this game.)
- The index in the character inventory tells you where you need to find all the items.

Cons
- Sloppy camera angle, which would be good for a simcity kind of game.
- The amount of grinding you have to do to achieve the next lvl is overboard
- Advance items are only in the later part of the game. 
  - example;  to craft a bow you have to wait until lvl 5. I would expect it a lvl 3
- Enemy weapons are more advance then yours.
- You can't make a raft and float it for the ocean Screaming at you new found friend Wilson!
- There is only one gender 
- The map looks like mincraft and yellow soap. (good news is you can see how close you are to the nearest enemy.)

If you got through this and if you think you manage I say it is well worth the investment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198389455706', 'num_games_owned': 25, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9255, 'last_played': 1565577528}
review:
I spent 95% of the time in gathering materials, making all kinds of things, and waiting water. Particularly at the last part of the game, you must combine all your 7 force of nature to become one piece, and with 5 of each gem: Ruby, Emerald, Onyx, Amethyst, Diamond, and Topaz, as well as 15 gold ingots. This part you  can do in two ways 1) Go back to kill monsters, and get random gems ( I don't  know how many percentages to get one chip), and 2) Plant hundreds of 6-color roses, make tubes by smelting sand to glass ingot and to glass tube, mix roses with the mill,  bring to Alchemist Desk to make chips, and  lastly combine 5 chip to one gem. These are no points to do all these processes.  If you are not prepared for this, just don't buy.

Pros: Beautiful Graphic and good environment

Cons: Everything takes longer time to complete
          Buildings are smaller and not fit in the place and looks unreal

author: {'steamid': '76561198324189612', 'num_games_owned': 156, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1600651180}
review: This game is decent at most. Everything feels super slow to do, mining, cutting down trees, digging, killing enemies, and even progression in general, especially with the stamina mechanic. Crafting shouldn't take as long as it does, and the game gets really stale when half of the time you're waiting for stuff to finish crafting. The map having to load a new area for you to go into it takes forever, and this is the only game I've ever seen that makes it seem sort of open world also forcing you into a loading screen every time you accidentally cross into part of the map that, for whatever reason, can't be loaded while the rest of the map is also loaded. Mutliplayer is also pretty bad. When one player dies, they both get sent back to spawn, and, last I checked, one player using a teleporter teleports both players to the teleporter on the other side. The game can be fun, but it gets boring quickly. I would not pay eight bucks for it.

review: Adoro esse jogo, mas eles poderiam melhorar o modo multiplayer porque d√° √∫ltima vez que joguei com a minha irm√£, ela n√£o recebeu as conquistas, somente eu que era dona do servidor!

author: {'steamid': '76561198020586563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1624, 'last_played': 1563435487}
review:
Like a 3d Version of minecraft. Except there's a stamina system that had me afking more than actually playing the game, just to recharge it.

If you play the game on the default setting, its just a massive grind and you struggle and feel trapped because better items is locked behind a level cap, which can only be raised by impossibly hard objectives compared to your level.

If you play in creative mode, there is no level cap on buildings or items. So its easy to skip 90% of the content without even getting to level 1. So basically you're stuck with impossibly hard (not challenging) or too easy to be fun.

In addition, when you do complete the game. All that happens is you get the option for a newgame+, nothing special.


Note: As far as I'm aware, This is a complete game that is no longer receiving updates but it definitely needs some. Namely balance and some form of automation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159860340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4501, 'last_played': 1573079121}
review: i LOVE this game! Don't need food or drink as a condition of survival, but use it to prevent battle death, and water grows crops and mixes potions. Enemies are a good mix of natural (bears, foxes, etc) and unnatural (trolls, animated skeletons, etc). And there is an ABUNDANCE of crafting to be done. Also, one can choose between quest mode (which is basically tutorial mode) or free range (which is your open sandbox freestyle). Great mix of survival and builder genres! I love it so much, i'm addicted! Don't change a THING!! Highly recommended!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198152069030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1562834378}
review:
Bad design on map and quest, funny gestures and terrible UI, fights are totally inconvenient, extremely unfriendly to individual player, the worst part is, my game has been interrupted when I try to going a little bit further on the map, it saids 'loading the map' then the whole game freezed and automatically closed, I couldnt even finish the quest that called first fight and collect enough coins. 

To be sincerely, this is an unfinished game but published to soon for money. Won't suggest people to getting it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198174912554', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2114, 'last_played': 1548376149}
review:
Grind with no actual gameplay in sight: the game.

If you're into crafting/building stuff with a slight touch of occasional combat, it's decent. But overall 90% of the game is waiting on ore to smelt, food to cook, etc, and the only other thing to do is fight things, and the combat is slow, dull, boring, cumbersome and just bad. It's better with friends, and the multiplayer works fine, but i really just wouldn't bother.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145557007', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 4569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3728, 'last_played': 1630901193}
review:
En mi opini√≥n es un buen juego, es bastante relajante y muy bonito <3.

Este juego sali√≥ de la greenlight en el 2016 y desear√≠a que el creador trabajara mas en el, me agrada as√≠ como esta pero no estar√≠a mal que agregara mas contenido. De momento el personaje solo puede ser masculino y no se puede personalizar mucho, solo puedes cambiarle el color de la piel, el de la ropa y el del cabello. La construcci√≥n no es tan libre como en otros juegos en los que haces tu casa cubo por cubo, pero aun as√≠ es agradable ver como se levanta s√≥lita tu casa despu√©s de un tiempo ya que todo en force of nature se basa en el tiempo (todos los crafteos y construcciones que hagas tienen cierto tiempo predeterminado en terminar de construirse). No hay muchos estilos de combate, pero para mi es suficiente con espada, arco y molotovs (aun que hay gente que prefiere b√°culos y conjuros, dagas r√°pidas o escudos). El juego tiene varios biomas y para acceder a algunos necesitas cierto tipo de armadura o ropas ya que tienen distintas temperaturas, lamentablemente algunas de esas ropas no tiene mucha defensa y cualquier enemigo te parte en dos r√°pido. Estar√≠a bien si agregara armaduras mejoradas (o alguna mesa para reforzarlas).

Force of nature es un juego de supervivencia y jugarlo con amigos es aun mas divertido (y te acelerar√≠a y facilitar√≠a mas las cosas  en caso de que seas alguien desesperado), es en un extenso mundo abierto con varios biomas, climas, enemigos diferentes pertenecientes a sus biomas (como puedes ver los v√≠deos), puedes domesticar animales como vacas, pollos, ovejas, etc y construir as√≠ tu granjita. Tambi√©n puedes tener tus campos de cultivos (aun que todo esto es realmente necesario si quieres sobrevivir, no es opcional...o si?...), al explorar encontraras distintas platas las cuales te soltaran algunas semillas que puedes usar para cultivarlas en tu terreno. Tiene algunas mesas de crafteo las cuales cada una tiene distinto prop√≥sito, esta la mesa para hacer armaduras, para cocinar, para pociones, etc. Como mencione anteriormente las cosas se basan en el tiempo y lo que me gusta es que puedes dejar tus cosas creandose mientras vas a por mas recursos, a cazar, matar enemigos o simplemente a explorar. El juego tambi√©n cuenta con misiones las cuales te sirven de gu√≠an y para avanzar en el juego. Entre otras buenas cositas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062387891', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 708, 'last_played': 1661859400}
review:
I had this game on my 'Wishlist' for a very long time and to be honest.. the Graphics weren't the reason to get it. 


But now I made the move and got the game and I had not regret it. 


Everything as old as it's looks.. just fits perfectly in this game. It is a great survival experience and the ration of occupation due to working and getting something in reward from it, is very nice. -- I need to do something and after a short while I get something and it does not feel like grinding stupidly for hours. -- This is a very big plus for this kind of game!

The only thing that is a bit of a minor issue for me, that you cannot interact with 'E' e.g. Go to a Table and work on it. I need to Push 'I' or 'Space' and then 'click', and for me it would be very nice to just press 'E' and then get into the crafting Interface.. it is just one step less for interaction and would make the usability of things much smoother. But this is just my opinion :)

++++++++++++

If you like Survival and a good feeling than this game might be the right thing for you! 

PS* I like this game a lot! Thank you Dev! :)

Kind Regards,
Merturion

author: {'steamid': '76561198018862288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1562022916}
review:
I saw someone else say that the videos for this game were misleading, and I'd agree.  I'd also add that the description is no better.

The controls are AWFUL.  The video shows someone moving around and mousing over items, but in the game I was playing, the mouse cursor isn't a thing.  The mouse is used purely for turning movment - ONLY when the HUD is off, mind you.  So here's how it works at the moment: do you want to look around?  You have to turn off the HUD.  Do you want to look at the HUD?  You have to sacrifice the ability to look around.  (Note: you can never look up.  Like, not even enough to see the tops of the trees you're chopping down.  Which is a really great way to make a game that is about being OUTDOORS feel super claustrophobic.) The HUD includes those labels showing up over items that show up that someone in the video gets by using a mouseover.  So your choices for gathering are: 1) run around with free movement but with no idea what you're looking at, or even what is and isn't an interactible item, spamming the left ctrl and alt keys in the hopes that you pick up anything and everything you might need, or 2) run around with the ability to spot what is and isn't an item, as well as which are items you need, but sacrifice the ability to turn around, or 3) a super annoying combo of turning the HUD on and off for a combo of 'best' of both worlds (the word 'best' is used veeeeeeery loosely).  I went looking in the controls sure there must be a way to customize this but no, the controls are very basic and you're stuck with it the way it is.

Now, about the description: in spite of the FIRST SENTENCE claiming this "is a Sandbox game" - it's NOT.  The leveling system is a tedious grind of nothing but fetch quests.  Except there's not even NPCs involved.  It's just you and a badly designed HUD telling you what you're going to do next if you want to play its game.  You can't even just go find and build stuff in your own order either, no, you have to follow the EXACT path the game has set for you if you want to level, and by leveling, get access to building anything other than the things it has decided you are allowed to build right now.  If you think "well I'll just take a break from leveling and explore" - TOO BAD!  You're also boxed in by plants that are magically impassible despite the fact that they're just giant ferns and aloe-looking plants, which should be super simple to push through.  It's tedious to find the ingredients, per my paragraph above.  It's tedious to find the ingredients in another way, too: figuring out WHAT provides WHICH ingredient.  You just have to run around with a VERY limited stamina bar that is VERY slow to rebuild, even with eating, and smack things over and over and over looking for what you need. And the logic is... questionable.  An example besides the one about not being able to walk through bushes: since you can get the exact same palm leaves from either palm trees or banana trees despite their having different leaves, you'd THINK you could turn some of those huge logs into sticks with your axe, yeah?  HA HA HA.  Silly survivalist.  No, you can't.  Go find sticks.  If you've used up the few on the ground, have fun chopping down everything trying to figure out where they come from.  Oh what's that, every tree should drop sticks?  HA HA HA.  Silly survivalist.

Also, note that the video only shows one swing of the axe or pick?  The reason for that is that it's a very slow process.  As is just moving, which I'm guessing is why they keep speeding up the video to avoid people noticing (and hey, in their defense, it worked on me). They also show things being taken down in 1 chop.  At level 1-3, at least, it takes you 3 swings to take down a fern.  6+ for a tree, not including trunk.  More tedium.

Crafting is also brushed over - in the video they're just slapping stuff down and BANG! It's there.  In the game, it's on a timer system, so you either stand there and stare at a timer counting down, or go gather some more... I guess... nothing else to do...

This game has both bored and irritated me - the worst combination.  I've spent just under an hour getting to level 3.  My hand is sore from holding down the mouse key to kick, or punch, or chop, or whatever variation on the left mouse click I'm supposed to be doing for the most recent quest.  I have no wish to keep following a straight line of "make this/gather this/build this" quests.  I bought it on sale for under $3, and I still feel like it wasn't worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028993278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3213, 'last_played': 1561267152}
review: If you like mindlessly collecting inordinate quantities of water to grow your rose garden - then this is your game. If you like waiting 20 minutes for your batch of coffee to brew, and then forcing your character to down all 60 coffees in 5 minutes during an intense tree cutting session - then this is the game for you. If you get off on being attacked by an endless number of bears and boars - this is your game. If you like the idea of forcing yourself to continue playing this game for hours to create the elusive Force Of Nature, so that you can FINALLY see a long awaited, complex, story-rich ending - then this game is the pinnacle and you will find no better way to let yourself down. Perfect game. 5/7

author: {'steamid': '76561198062225355', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1561651546}
review:
I am giving a positive but kind of on the fence. It is a good game and it is fun. It looks really good, camera angles are not bad overall. The game has some cool building and the exploration is really nice. I am liking the crafting and stuff. 

Now for the but, but the stamina drain is just awful. The stamina is a little to in your face for me.  The stamina seems to really slow your progression a lot, I don't have a problem that you have to deal with stamina I just feel it drains way to fast and it turns the game into a eating simulator.  Swing a pick or axe a few times and your out of stamina so you have to eat eat and eat and eat and eat, swing your tools a few more times and it's back to eat eat eat and eat. 

I leveled up enough to start crafting higher tier tools. You would think that better tools are going to make your life better. I was not feeling that, I seemed to be losing the same amount of stamina per swing with the better tools as the stone tools. So it didn't seem to help with stamina so you would think you could break rocks or chopper trees with less swings, which would use less stamina overall but it didn't. If it was making a difference it was so minor of a change that you don't feel like your progressing, which I started to get bored and I quit. I will most likely go back and play it some time in the future and if some mods came out for it I would definitely revisit the game.

So the game has some really cool stuff in it and some good mechanics, I just feel the stamina drags down the whole game. I feel it could use a serious tweak but that's just my opinion. Even something like a slider option so you could adjust how fast or slow your stamina drains would be cool.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031317790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1562211316}
review:
I want to like this game. Don't get me wrong I do like it but at times it is still a bit clunky with the mechanics. For instance inventory management. You have to have the material in your personal inventory in order to craft an item, it cant just be in a chest near your crafting bench. So then when you want to go out exploring you have to take out all the things you don't want the possibility of losing if you die. Then when you get back from exploring and have all that sweet loot but still need to start crafting again, you guessed it you have to play musical chairs with your inventory and a chest or two to take out the stuff you don't need and add the stuff you do need. It is a problem that could be fixed by just allowing crafting out of your stored inventory. 

Now onto combat.... frustrating would be the word I would use to describe it! At the time of writing this I am only a level 6 and grinding away at finding the 75 gold coins needed to make the 5 gold bars that I need to get to level 7. Why do I put this comment in the combat part of this review? Because the only way that I have found so far to get gold coins is your going to guess it again... combat! Now what is wrong with that, nothing, as long as you don't mind potentially watching your loot run over that hill into the sunset. What do I mean by that? Well sometimes you get attacked by a goblin or two or three and you fight back getting one down to a small amount of health just to watch them run away.... give chase.... not an option you are far slower than them... try to shoot them with your bow... yeah there is a slight chance you will hit them... pound your face on the keyboard out of frustration... that's the right option! Oh and don't even get me started on foxes!

After all that complaining I still find myself wanting to play, wanting to get to that next level, wanting to craft that better gear.....

author: {'steamid': '76561198011838061', 'num_games_owned': 485, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1563384899}
review:
Alors, par quoi commencer. Ce jeu est excellent.

- Graphisme:
 Le jeu est propre, les graphismes sont jolis, bien d√©taill√©s, rien √† redire √† ce sujet.

- Gameplay:
 Il y a un but dans ce jeu, en soit nous ne sommes pas largu√© sur une √Æle sans aucun objectif autre que la survie.
Mais pour d√©couvrir ce qui nous attend, il faut un peu jou√© dessus. 
Le jeu ne cesse de me surprendre. Je suis un adepte de l'apprentissage par moi m√™me. A ce niveau, le jeu nous guide parfaitement, chaque √©tape nous conduit √† diff√©rents crafts et nouvelles fonctionnalit√© qui me r√©jouie toujours plus. 
Cependant sachez que le jeu est chronophage (qu'il prend du temps) et que pour avancer un temps soit peu il faut √™tre patient, m√™me si globalement on peut tout faire rapidement si l'on est organiser.

- Difficult√©: 
Je suis mort plusieurs fois, la faune est hostile, alors prudence, surtout si vous avez un peu de loot "pr√©cieux", vous risquez des pertes.
La n√©cessit√© de manger n'est pas importante, en tout cas √† l'heure actuelle.

Je n'ai pour l'heure rencontr√© aucun probl√®me, ni crash, ni bug visuel. Ce jeu est une perle √† acheter sans mod√©ration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076717643', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1995, 'last_played': 1560390207}
review:
This game had potential, but it would seem the developers' abandoning it has made it nothing but a reminder that God has abandoned us. 

This game is incredibly painful to play and I wish I had never been lured into it. It looks like an absolutely wonderful game on the surface and it's arguably decent in-game at times as well, but when it comes to progressing in the game there's no excuse for how poorly executed it is. 

You first wake up on a beach and are prompted to go around collecting and harvesting your surroundings in order to level up your character. Note that your character can only level up upon completing certain tasks; there's no experience system and no way to level up your health or stamina other than by completing those tasks. This would be perfectly fine if the tasks they asked you to complete weren't as irritating and annoying as possible (and sometimes useless). One of the tasks has you capturing animals with a net, but the capture rate for these nets feels like 20% at best. In my experience, out of 15 nets thrown, 3 will ever capture the animal. Going further on the capture front, you are eventually granted the ability to catch goblins; however, these goblins are basically useless when it comes to combat and die within seconds of being attacked.

To be fair, I have never been able to capture level 20 goblins, only ever level 1-3 goblins; this brings me to my next point. If you want to explore an area that you're able to explore temperature-wise (there's a temperature system in the game that prevents you from exploring higher-level areas without the proper equipment) but if your level is lower than the enemies in the area, you are going to be annihilated. Some mobs will chase you to across the entire map to put axes to kneecaps, some mobs will hit you with a poison who's virulence would rival the most concentrated dose of potassium cyanide or hemlock, some mobs will stun lock you with their attacks and just melt your health away, some mobs have a melee attack with a radius to rival that of our planet, and some mobs just like to steal 2/3 of your health before running away from you at break-neck speeds once you get them close to death. With regards to the last mob, those are usually the creatures that you NEED to kill in order to get materials to progress in the game. Luckily for you though there's archery in the game so you could shoot an arrow into the mob before it runs away; however, the mobs have evidently acquired the ability to enter bullet-time and weave through your arrows like Gru weaves through missiles. 

So to recap, we have enemies that either destroy you within seconds of meeting them or run away from you after bringing you close to death, we have a progression system that is locked until you can complete whatever arbitrary tasks the game has set for you, we have a mob-capture system that is infuriating to work with, and we have the ability to turn enemies into piss-poor allies that are weaker than their enemy variants.

Aside from that, the game is ridiculously heavy on the farming front: if you don't farm then you will almost certainly never beat the game. Personally, I'm alright with a bit of farming, but when the entire game becomes almost unplayable without you having to farm thousands of stalks of wheat and coffee beans then I get a little peeved. 

I feel as though I should also address some of the things that brought me into this game, mainly the pictures and videos showcasing it. First of all, flint doesn't exist in this game so whatever version they're using is clearly not the one you're paying for. Second of all, building is in no way, shape, or form as easy as the first video makes it seem. If you want to build a base like you see in the video then you'll need to farm resources for around an hour or two in real time, not to mention that if you want the big mill that's showcased then you need to play the game until you're max level, which means dealing with all the irritating and unbalanced bullshit that I've made note of in this review. Also, catching all of those animals will require upwards of 100 nets and at least 45 minutes of your time scouring the island for an animal to catch (and when you finally find one and try to catch it, chances are the net will break and the animal will sprint into a horde of hostile mobs. Hooray.) Third of all, all of those goblins attacking the base were most likely spawned in by the developer because unless he built his base off of the shore and into the hostile woods, it is incredibly unlikely that that many goblins will ever attack you. You might get one or two that slip between the trees and attack your buildings, but never six or seven (not in my experience at least.) Fourth of all, the clothing you need to explore some of the temperature-locked zones often has no defense value, so you will be eaten alive by whatever mobs decide to target you in their absurdly large area of aggression. Additionally, kiting mobs is futile as they will always land one to two hits on you unless you hide behind obstacles or get supremely lucky. Your only viable option when facing a mob is to beat the hell out of it and hope you can kill it before it kills you. Keep in mind that the mob will be landing two hits on you constantly whilst your character can only land one whilst he swings his weapon with the speed of the bathroom troll from Harry Potter. Fifth of all, I just tried this myself and maracas do jack shit. The developer had to have been in creative mode to not be attacked by that fox because the maracas have no anti-aggression capabilities whatsoever. They are a completely useless cosmetic item that, if I heard correctly, make no noise at all (so basically, they aren't maracas). The in-game description says they deal damage but, unless I'm clicking the wrong left mouse button, that's pure fallacy.

With regards to the second video, playing this game with friends seems like the only way to not lose hair playing it; however, I have never seen an online multiplayer game open so, unless your friend has this game, there's no chance of you finding another person to play with.

As one final note of grievance, the terrain in this game is appalling. Have you ever wanted to get stuck between two trees that are at least 3 feet apart? Have you ever wanted to be backed into a corner by mobs because something that you thought would have obviously been a path, wasn't? Have you ever wanted to carve your way through the trees chopping 3-4 trees before your stamina bar depletes entirely and you have to either use items you've farmed to restore it or wait 1.5-2.5 in-game days to replenish it all? Have you ever wanted to jump into a game to take control of the character because the gap in the trees is big enough for a goddamn ogre to fit through but apparently your skinny ass can't manage it? If you answered yes to any of these questions, then by all means purchase this game and feed money into the hands of the developers who no longer care about this game. To be fair though, they could have just lost all the data for this game in a fire, been kidnapped by whatever mafia they angered with this game, had to surrender their dreams of developing games to support their families, or could have simply decided that the game was a waste of time and abandoned it (something I wish I did a long time ago).

In all honesty, this is a great game if you play it in creative mode. The ambiance and natural flora are beautiful and you can make some really nice compounds with the structures programmed into the game. However, if you want to play this game as an island survival RPG full of daring adventure and mystical whimsy, then run as fast as you possibly can away from this store page.

This game gets a 1.5/10 from me, and I hope you never get the chance to rate it because if you do then that means you fell for the same trap that I did. If that's the case, then welcome to Hell: you won't go gently into this good night.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037563217', 'num_games_owned': 605, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1579710550}
review:
Generally I would recommend this game albeit despite some flaws with it. 

It's a fun and enjoyable crafting/sandbox(ish)/RPG/survival game with plenty to do, a nice progression introducing you to new items and constructions to make and a story line which so far isn't too bad (although it may change when I get to the ending).
Controls actually work well with the gather key being CTRL and gather all ALT, which makes for some quick item picking. Graphics are just fine, nothing fancy but not outdated either (almost classic in a sense) and the AI is generally ok, although there have been moments of it getting stuck on some random bush here and there. The challenge in this game is there and you will be spending ages making the perfect little hamlet.

Despite this there are a few things which are either annoying or just strange. The stamina will be the bane of your life in this game. Countless times I go roaming around to mine for ores and I forget to pack lots of stamina recovery items (not that there are load mind you) and have to wait a while to get back to 100%. Just make sure you pack enough coffee. Also the UI is pretty clunky and takes a bit of getting used to. Progress is very slow in this game, so don't expect a breeze through at all which for some is off putting. I've not had the chance to try multiplayer (no one I know has this game) so I cannot comment on it other than to hear that it works somewhat and does make the game a lot easier to finish.

A nice game to play although not for the feint of heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030374060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 1741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1741, 'last_played': 1555393875}
review:
What to say about this game?  Force of Nature is a game.  I can't say it's a good game.  It's not a bad game, either, it's just another game.  It's another game about building a base, building small buildings, building buildings to allow you to make stuff to build more buildings, and building more buildings to let you make stuff you can use to kill stuff so you can get their stuff and use it to build more buildings.  Fascinating.

For a few hours.  Then you realize you've seen this all before.  In triple A games straight down to horrible and abandoned indie games you've seen variations on this theme.

It's a good theme.   It's a good formula.  It will entertain you long enough that you can't ask for a refund from Steam because your play time is over the limit.  It doesn't lend itself well for long term replay unless you add a whole lot more twists, character development, free flow research trees, tons of customization for players to allow variations in game play strategy and results... but this game has none of that.  It's a very linear tech tree... I'd call it a tech log...  there are no branches.  

The graphics are plain, the controls are usable, although unwieldy for certain tasks, the quests seem mainly put there as obstacles rather than fun things to accomplish.  It's not that this game isn't polished.  A lot of work went into it.  I love indie games, and I love builders and management games and fighting games... but this game just gets boring very quick and just isn't that good.  

If you get Force of Nature for a price that you consider super cheap, and want to blow 20 hours with it and then be prepared to move on, then go for it.  I would want  more from a software package that I've written, and perhaps the developers of this game have grandiose plans to make this a completely different end product when it's finished.  I hope they can do it.  For now, it's just not that good.

I got what I expected from it.  Nothing more, nothing less.  I love indie's so I'm gonna recommend it.  But it's a recommendation with an *...

author: {'steamid': '76561197992588313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1555686068}
review:
This could have been a good game, but at the current patch level it is a rather good example on how to NOT create  a game.
Why?
- The worls has way more monsters (Goblins) even at low level than it has animals at all (i guess by factor 5-6).
- Especially the taming system is ... inferior.
- Monsters and animals respawn every time you load the game, but plants not. That for such could have been nice, but it is tiresome to clear again and again and again.... especially with the problem that you have always way more monsters than animals as already mentioned before
- You can set chest only in houses, so you wind up with you inverntory flooded by things you can not really store

author: {'steamid': '76561198018471937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 1951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1555740926}
review:
At first, I thought this was not a very good game but recently, I gave it another try.  There is a lot more to this game than first meets the eye and the depth and execution of the game is actually done quite well compared to other games of similar genres.  The game is probably best with at least 1 friend (you can play with up to 4 people on a single game).

Seems to be worth the money at full price (currently $7.99 US).

Update: After playing for a while, the game got somewhat stale and repetitive.  Also, the need to use magic items was a disappointment with a name like "Force of Nature" since this has the implication of using natural means to deal with issues in the game, and I don't like magic or things related to magic.

Leaving as recommended for now...

author: {'steamid': '76561198178985042', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1556469632}
review:
√â um bom jogo pra quem gosta do estilo, mas o desenvolvimento √© um pouco lento j√° que o jogo te obriga a ir dropar uma tonelada de itens para subir de level. O craft depende do n√≠vel, tornando um jogo um pouco travado no in√≠cio.

Com certeza vale os 8 reais (promo√ß√£o), na verdade vale at√© mais.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005974119', 'num_games_owned': 905, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1184, 'last_played': 1524850339}
review:
H√∂rt sich vllt. komisch an aber mich entspannt und beruhigt dieses Spiel total :)

Das Spielprinzip ist simpel gehalten, man muss verschiedene Quest abschlie√üen, Sachen craften, Ressourcen abbauen und z. B Objekt A erstellen um  Geb√§ude B zu errichten um dann nach C zu gelangen. 
Das Kampfsystem ist so naja und nebensache, da es sich viel mehr auf crafting und in (Survival) fixiert. 

Wer nach einem stressigen Tag paar Stunden abschalten m√∂chte und kein anspruchsvolles Gameplay erwartet, dem empfehle ich dieses Spiel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198367529952', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1696359080}
review:
Right off the bat I thought that I probably would be buying a game that I would soon be refunding.  But this game has all the elements in a survival game that I crave so I decided to give it a try.  I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed playing this game.  I highly recommend this game to new players or kids looking to get into this genre of games as it has plenty of instructions and is simple to play in comparison to many games like these that just drop you off on a piece of land with maybe a book, maybe...  Only thing I was confused about in the beginning was how to go about getting more sticks and such, but a simple right click to kick trees and bushes gave me the items, not too bad at all. edit: also using left ctrl a lot saves you tons of time instead of looting piece by piece, this button loots all at once.
The bad thing so far is the ugly character, but sad to say i've seen worse, not a deal breaker. 
Got it on sale but I would have paid the whole $8 and been happy still.  Good buy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198276517750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 11565, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11093, 'last_played': 1643721774}
review:
Alors je reviens donner mon avis apr√®s 185h de jeux (ouais, ouais, je suis un dingue).
J'y ai pas mal jouer en solo et encore plus en duo.

Nous avons retourn√© le jeu en mode classique et l√† nous sommes pass√©s en mode sans limites.

Les moins :
- Graphismes assez dat√©s
- Quelques bug de chargement
- En multi : Si un joueur meurt, l'autre meurt aussi...
- Des gisements inaccessibles
- Les menus un peu chiants quand on veut encha√Æner la m√™me chose

Les plus :
- Addictif
- Simple et efficace
- Beaucoup de choses √† construire
- Des maps super grandes √† explorer

Bref, un excellent passe temps (et plus si affinit√©s), en promo c'est toujours mieux.
La difficult√© m'inqui√©tais jusqu'√† ce que je trouve la technique et c'est devenu une promenade de sant√©.

Ceux qui aiment le farming et ne pas se prendre la t√™te, ce jeu et fait pour vous

author: {'steamid': '76561198008493276', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1554207774}
review:
An sich ist die Idee hinter dem Spiel ganz gut, aber die Umsetzung passt nicht wirklich. In den Neuigkeiten wurde seitens des Entwicklers das letzte Mal im April 2018 (also vor genau einem Jahr) ein Beitrag geschrieben. Man kann also davon ausgehen, dass das Spiel nicht weiterentwickelt wird.

Was mich am Gameplay st√∂rt:

- Der Charakter ist wirklich eine lahme Ente.
- Man kann nur selten zwischen B√§umen und B√ºschen durchlaufen. Alles muss niedergem√§ht werden.
- Die Crafting/Baumen√ºs sind zwar nicht wirklich umst√§ndlich, aber nervig, da man bspw am Amboss stets "Leertaste" dr√ºcken muss um den Amboss dann mit der Maus auszuw√§hlen, dann den Reiter "Rezepte" w√§hlen muss, sich dann ein Rezept raussucht, um dann festzustellen das noch etwas fehlt. Also alles wieder schlie√üen, ben√∂tigten Gegenstand farmen oder craften, alle Men√ºs wieder √∂ffnen um das Gew√ºnschte herzustellen. Nervt√∂tend f√ºr mich. Wenn es bspw wie bei Terraria w√§re: Neben der Schmelze steht, Men√º √∂ffnen, sehen was man bauen kann, anklicken, fertig. Nein, nicht bei FoN. Hier braucht jeder Gegenstand mehrere Sekunden bis Minuten. Und eine Reihenfolge des zu craftenden wie bspw bei Rust kann man auch nicht anlegen. Alles muss nacheinander gemacht werden.
- Grinden, grinden, grinden, grinden, grinden, grinden.
- F√ºr die einzelnen LevelUps braucht man M√ºnzen oder Material oder sogar noch erf√ºllte Quests um weiterzukommen.

Wie es im sp√§teren Spielverlauf ist, kann ich nicht sagen, da mir nach 90 Minuten bereits der Geduldsfaden mit diesem ewigen gegrinde gerissen ist.

F√ºr Leute, die es wirklich lieber entspannter angehen und grinden √ºber alles lieben mag dieser Titel ja eine Option sein. Aber nicht f√ºr mich.

review:
game not finish.
the game need a lot of upgrade, more water(speed up or remove the limit of 6per well)
the only help is a goblin and only for fight (and only one at the same time, but we need few of them to protect our base/house/animals/wall.
to craft few item we need to build in a house, but the limited area, and the limited number of house allow make the area really short, and to upgrade this limit we have to level up, but with level up we need more place...the same for water, more cow, chicken, to feed them we need water, and an other item, for this item we need water, but the limited number of well and the limited number of water per well(6) make the water always not enough. when we use wheat seed we have a lot of wheat seed a few wheat to use for cow or flour. the game need a balancing after dev try the game to understand there are few problem.

the only good point is :
the difficult of the game make the player need to use all new item unlock by a level up everytime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198283426181', 'num_games_owned': 72, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1235, 'last_played': 1553578277}
review: This is not a good game. Its very poorly designed and unbalanced. They use a level-based crafting system instead of a skill-based crafting system which forces your character to complete specific objectives in order to be able to craft and build new items and structures, the monsters and animals are significantly faster than the character making it impossible to retreat and heal during a fight and the amount of damage the monsters and animals do is to high for the level they are. A level 6 character will lose 1/3 of there health to a level 1 Boar before it dies and it will run away and regenerate its health when it gets low. Not recommended do not waste your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990742623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1552823477}
review:
Pros: Interesting setting and pleasing graphics.

Cons: Clunky UI that makes it hard to do nearly everything from simply picking up items to harvesting resources.
For example, just to harvest berries from a bush you need to hold down space and click on the name that shows when space is held. The bush then breaks into multiple items which you'll either need to hold space and click on each name to pick up or (if you happen to notice it in the settings) you can press ctrl to pickup all items nearby.

In summary, I'm certain that most people will find this game's UI frustrating to navigate and will quickly bore of the grindy nature of combat/resource collection.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988275125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1554038760}
review:
You will spend quite a lot of time crafting, farming needed resources around your starting point before going exploring far away otherwise you will be killed by bears or other creatures. The progress is slow so you will need patience if you're an adventurer.
Giving the fact that the price is decent (you can also wait for a sale to buy it), I recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122266671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3407, 'last_played': 1543615328}
review:
Force of Nature √® un gioco meraviglioso che mi ha letteralmente rapito. Innanzi tutto √® supportato da un sistema di costruzione e crafting davvero geniale, unico, chiaro e semplice da imparare. Si possono creare tantissime cose, ma quello che pi√π diverte √® la costruzione del proprio villaggio, personalizzabile in tutto e per tutto con edifici vari e moltissimi elementi decorativi (strade, sentieri, lampioni, fiori, recinti con gli animali ecc.). E' un gioco unico e molto originale, grazie alle dinamiche classiche di esplorazione e survival unite ad elementi fantasy.
L'esplorazione √® un aspetto assolutamente affascinante di questo gioco, il quale presenta tante ambientazioni del tutto diverse tra loro, come il paesaggio tropicale, il deserto, la foresta, le montagne innevate, il mare, le paludi e molto altro ancora. L'aspetto che pi√π mi ha affascinato del gioco √® proprio la bellezza delle ambientazioni e dei paesaggi: chilometri di esplorazione immersi nella natura pi√π incontaminata, con scenari suggestivi, idilliaci, meravigliosi e affascinanti. La natura in tutta la sua bellezza √® resa davvero bene in questo gioco, nonostante la semplice grafica. Ho apprezzato molto gli scorci, come il ruscello, il laghetto col canneto, la radura con i fiori, la nebbia nella foresta, le fitte pinete e moltissimi altri elementi incantevoli.
Un altro punto di forza del gioco sono i nemici che si possono incontrare durante il viaggio, tutti molto vari e ben disegnati: ce ne sono di tantissimi tipi, sia realistici sia fantasy, e cambiano a seconda delle ambientazioni. Anche le armi e le armature meritano, sono molto varie e ben fatte con un tocco di fantasy e medievale. Peccato per il sistema di combattimento che considero l'unico difetto del gioco: √® molto rudimentale ed √® stato poco approfondito, legnoso e lento, ma vista la variet√† e la bellezza del gioco ci si abitua e passa in secondo piano.
Il gioco presenta un'ottima longevit√†, circa 50 ore per essere completato e dopodich√® si √® liberi di continuare la propria avventura all'infinito, andando avanti ad esplorare, combattere e costruire. Un gioco davvero stupendo. Lo consiglio a tutti.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029908385', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1564608220}
review:
Wow!

J'ai trouv√© mon jeu, du moins, un parmi le genre de jeu qui me rejoint.

Cela fait plusieurs jours d√©j√† que j'y joue, je peux donc exprimer plus facilement s'il est ou non un bon jeu. En fait non pas si c'est un bon jeu, plut√¥t, si j'aime ou j'aime pas ce jeu, parce que tout est relatif, tout est personnel.

Alors donc, pour ce jeu, j'aime vraiment beaucoup!  Il est sensationnel.
Un jeu de type "open-world", dont on y joue "hors-ligne"(√ßa c'√©tait un de mes crit√®res principales) et par le fait m√™me, en solo(un autre de mes crit√®res).

On d√©bute, √† ce qui me semble √™tre, √† l'√¢ge de pierre.
On √©volue, √† notre rythme, en amassant diverses ressources  et minerais pour pouvoir √©riger un petit domaine d'o√π construira les installations propres aux transformations des diff√©rents minerais en m√©taux utilisables, les produits de notre cueillette, les confections artisanales et d'outils ainsi que d'armes.

On rencontre des "mods" qui en les combattant, relativement ais√©ment selon notre protection, nos armes ainsi que les consommables pour nous r√©g√©n√©rer, nous donnerons des produits tout aussi utiles √† cr√©er d'autres utilitaires.

Il y a aussi diff√©rents "biomes" o√π il nous sera indispensables, selon la temp√©rature, d'avoir pr√©alablement con√ßu les v√™tement de protection thermique ad√©quat, selon le cas.

Un point tr√®s agr√©able du jeu, qui se r√©v√®le assez vite d'une grande aide, est la cr√©ation, entre autre, de "Portails".
Il conviendra d'an cr√©er deux(2) au minimum pour pouvoir aller d'un point √† un autre, sans refaire tout le trajet du retour pour gagner notre domaine.
√Ä noter, que pour cr√©er un autre portail, il faut √™tre en dehors de la fronti√®re de chaque portails, d√©finit sous un grand cercle rose-p√¢le sur la carte que l'on fait appara√Ætre.

J'adore tout simplement ce jeu, avec ses chants d'oiseaux et d'autres animaux d'√©levages et sauvages.
C'est relaxant, tout aussi que cr√©atif et de style "survie", vu que l'on doit d√©couvrir diff√©rents secteurs de la carte et la rencontre de diff√©rents "mod" √† combattre.

Bref, je le recommande fortement, √† qui convient ce genre de jeu.
J'esp√®re qu'il y aura des mis √† jours et de nouvelles d√©couvertes.

Merci et √† bient√¥t.
Cordialement,
Carl-Dave
PS: Ce qui est bizarre c'est que cela fait presque une semaine que je joue √† raison de plusieurs heures par jour √† ce jeu. Cependant, lors de la cr√©ation de mon commentaire, celui-ci, le site m'√©crit que √ßa doit faire au moins cinq(5) minutes que l'on doit y jouer pour poster un commentaire, et que √ßa ne fait pas encore cinq(5) minutes que j'y ais jou√©.
Vraiment bizarre.

Saludos a todos, les comentar√© mi apreciaci√≥n.
A este juego le di bastantes buenas horas, y si, lo recomiendo, y estas son mis apreciaciones:
- No es juego demasiado largo, si lo vicias, por ende, es bueno darle quiz√° un par de horitas de corrido para que se pueda disfrutar

- El tema del inventario quizas sea un poco mejorable por lo dem√°s esta bi√©n.
- El aspecto visual creo que si vale la pena, tomando en cuenta el valor que tiene el juego, y que no fueron tantos los que trabajaron en el proyecto.
En general vale la pena, pero no es demasiado largo. T√≥menlo con calma ser√≠a mi conclusi√≥n

author: {'steamid': '76561198032027696', 'num_games_owned': 422, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 1625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1625, 'last_played': 1549693911}
review:
Nicht zu empfehlen, h√∂chstens im Angebot. Was Anfangs Spa√ü macht wird nach ein paar Spielstunden extrem monoton und langweilig. W√§hrend man zu Beginn die Gegend erkundet und seine Basis aufbaut muss man sich nach den ersten Fortschritten f√ºr jede Kleinigkeit [b]Tonnen[/b] von Rohstoffen besorgen. Das w√§re an sich kein Problem. Nur l√§uft das komplette Spiel total langsam. Laufen, Abbauen, K√§mpfen oder Craften; alles l√§uft wie in Zeitlupe ab. Hinzu kommt der steigende Schwierigkeitsgrad. Schaden und Gesundheit der Gegner steigen, wo hingegen die Waffen und R√ºstungen des Charakters zu schwach sind. Das sorgt daf√ºr, dass man trotz bester Ausr√ºstung immer mehr Treffer pro Gegner ben√∂tigt oder eben schneller stirbt.

[h1]Positiv[/h1]
 - Grafik, Sound, Musik sowie Steuerung sind in Ordnung
 - Sinnvolles Crafting-System
 - Viele Geb√§ude, Waffen, R√ºstungen und Gegenst√§nde
 - Viele M√∂glichkeiten Basis zu erweitern

[h1]Negativ[/h1]
 - Zu langsames Gameplay
 - Hitboxen von Str√§ucher oder B√§umen total bescheuert, man h√§ngt an Stellen fest wo eindeutig genug Platz w√§re
 - Kleinste Abh√§nge k√∂nnen nicht betreten werden
 - Gegner werden st√§rker, Charakter hingegen trotz bester Ausr√ºstung nur marginal
 - Man muss zu viele Rohstoffe sammeln
 - Nerviges Grinden (nimmt mindestens 1/4 des Spiels ein!)
 - Regelm√§√üig Abst√ºrze

review: Zwei Punkte die mir dieses Spiel so sympatisch machen, sind einerseits die liebevolle Grafik und das gem√ºtliche Gameplay. Ich bin derzeit Level 7 und das steigende Grinding k√∂nnte den Spielspass mindern aber bisher macht mir es echt Spass. Das einzige was schade ist, wo ich gerne w√ºsste wie man es wieder aktiv bekommt, ist die Musik, die keinen Loop hat, trotz Option im Men√º. F√ºr den Preis wirklich eine Empfehlung und ich hoffe der Entwickler wird weiter daran arbeiten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038051417', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1545458195}
review:
I think I got this game on sale for about 50% off.  I got 4 hours out of it, so I guess it doesn't owe me anything but it got pretty boring pretty fast.
Even with the tutorial it was a bit tough figuring out how to make some things work and it looked to get pretty grindy in a big hurry.  Note to devs:  making things a grind doesn't add challenge, it just makes it an annoying time suck.
In general Force of Nature had some fun ideas, though none strikingly original.  What's in the game is well-executed but that's the other problem:  There's just not much to it.  It feels... incomplete.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053422960', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 28606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17626, 'last_played': 1609185650}
review:
First of all i wonna say i really love this game. It has all i want from a survival game and it is probably one of the best survival games out there.

Here is a listing of pro's and con's from me for this game:

Pro's:
[list]
[*] pretty nice, and detailed bioms and graphs made with love while my graphic card is not overheating
[*] wonderfull birdsongs in high quality and great nature sounds
[*] this game made me feel relaxed
[*] no food for hunger but for healing
[*] working multiplayer even in beta
[*] living at the beach creates holiday feelings
[/list]
Everything worked pretty well till three days ago. I had three worlds. Two old softcore and one new hardcore. A week ago one old softcore world vanished. I should have been alerted and should have saved my world immediately but I didnt. Three days ago I switched the game off in the evening two hours before I reached the end of the game. I had no gamecrashes nor pc crashes. When I turned on my pc again the next morning I loaded the last save game and started in the new hardcore world I created a month ago but without any clothes, buildings, loot and weapons. Everything was gone but the raw world and the creation dates of the save game files were set to a date two years ago. 

That brings me to the con's:
[list]
[*] You can't rely on the savegames what makes a game unplayable.
[*] The developer stopped supporting this game.
[/list]
I cant recomment this game cause of the problem with save games even if I would give it a 8 of 10 otherwise.

If you already bought this game and you want to be sure that you lose no data just save the world youre playing with (C:\ProgramData\ForceOfNature\Worlds\W00*) to a different location. I used 3 locations and I alternately saved after every game session to one of those locations.

[b]If somethings changes here I would be happy to change my review.[/b]

review:
Pros: Concept seems really awesome; artwork is nice.

Cons: Controls are terrible (have to hit 'Q' to switch into a mode to pick up things); could not get to level 2 and pass the tutorial missions because I could not find a palm on the ground... despite there being tons of palm trees and plants around.

It seems like a deep game, but I'll never see it because of a poorly made tutorial.

author: {'steamid': '76561198398370474', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1546616554}
review:
Forces of nature is a survival game with a slight fantasy twist to it, which is honestly one of the few things setting it apart from the dozens (if not hundreds) of other indie survival games on steam. However, Like so many of the dozens of indie survival games one finds on steam, nearly every aspect of it's core gameplay suffers from poor execution. Lets start with the basics:

-The game looks like it crawled out of a time warp leading 12+ years into the past. Unimpressive in literally every graphical regard except the water textures, even on ultra high (which by the why, there's no discernable difference between High and Ultra besides framerate dropping, at least that I could tell). I'm not usually one to care about graphics if the artistic style is consistent and/or the core gameplay is good, but well... read on.

-The soundtrack... I honestly don't think the game has one. For the life of me, I swear that every hour I've put into this thing, the only thing going in the background has been the various soundeffects. Not even a simple ambience track from what I could hear, nor combat music, nor anything. This is admittedly a minor thing, perhaps even a nitpick, but I feel that in hindsight, the lack of even such a basic element as this foreshadowed the quality of game overall.

-Some of the clunkiest controls I have seen in a long time. While yes, the scheme is functional on a technical level, it's awkward as hell to have to hold space and then click on the object to interact with [b]anything[/b] instead of say, just pressing E or something after getting close. Expect to take a good bit of time just getting used to the alien controls before you can start playing properly.

Now, into the meat and potatoes of the reveiw.

Whereas most indie survivals execute their gameplay poorly by requiring you to play metermaid for a character who can't go more than 10 in-game minutes without eating, drinking, sleeping, or taking a wee, Force of Nature's cardinal sin is of a different ilk, one that anyone who has played even a little bit of vanilla versions of Oblivion or older Elder Scrolls games will be quite familiar with: The Grind. The God. Damned. Grinding. Grinding not just for levels though, but for the basic resources you need to do pretty much [b]anything[/b] in this damn game too. Now, some might say "well grinding for resources is part of any survival game" and yeah, you're right. 

But the grind should never be this mind-numblingly boring. Boring because pretty much all of the actually interesting stuff is walled off by a level requirement until you've already invested several hours into the game; the trailers are somewhat misleading in this regard, given those bases and the boss raids they show are all *late game content*, and every moment of getting to that late game will be spent grinding your ass off.  For you see, there's actually quite a lot of things you can construct in this game, but if you play on "General" mode like the game suggests to new players, most of it will have to be unlocked by gaining levels. There are seven levels to my knowledge, each one unlocking a new teir of constructions and decorations, with the sixth to seventh levels being where the type of late game content in the trailers becomes available. To get a single level, you have to complete each quest associated with said level. And guess what these quests involve. Yes, grinding. You gotta grind stone deposits to get enough to make a blast furnace. Gotta grind trees and bushes to get enough wood and leaves to construct a straw hut. Grind sand and clay and dirt in order to construct Charcoal cookers, etc. Often, in order to finish a quest you'll need to make something using the new construction you just grinded to make. Well guess what, most of the crafting stations in the game require some form of tools in order to do anything on them, for added realism I suppose. In order to get those tools, you gotta grind some more, of course. There's nothing in most of the quest descriptions telling you "oh, and go ahead and make this tool while you're at it too, you'll need it for this". No, it just gets sprung on the player at the last minute once they realize they can't make anything at this damn construction they just spent the better part of an hour farming materials for, only to look under some of the recipes and see that doing anything at all requires another component to the crafting station that has to be made seperately from it. The vast majority of quests require you to do [i]some[/i] form of crafting in order to complete it, so you're going to run into this type of nonsense multiple times. 

The game does shake this frustrating monotny up a bit however, as some quests don't require you to farm resource nodes to complete them. They require you to farm mobs instead, whether by taming them, or by killing them. The former part is actually ok, but the latter part is where the second cardinal sin of the game comes in. It's half-assed combat system. [i]If one can even call it that[/i]. Really, it's nothing more than holding down the left or right mouse whilst vainly trying to plod your character side to side or backwards in order to dodge enemy attacks. Except your character moves so damn slowly, even after gaining several levels and increasing your speed with each one, that you might as well just save yourself the effort and stay stock still while you mindlessly wail away at the enemy. Just like you do while mining resource nodes... actually, know what? I lied earlier, it [i]doesn't[/i] shake things up by making you slay mobs, the monsters are all just destructable obstacles/resource nodes by another name, that happen to actually move and might hit you back. That goblin is really just an angry tree, take an axe to it as you would any other. But be forewarned, since all the mobs are also massive damage sponges- even a god damn rabbit, big as they may be in this game, will take numerous hits from a stone knife, the most basic tool/weapon, before they drop dead. Every other mob just gets worse from there. You'd never think that sheep, foxes, chickens, etc could take a lot of punishment, but you'd be surprised how much health this game sees fit to give them. Gods help you if you decide to take on a bear, especially below at least level 5-6.

And well, thats basically the game, if you play it as recommended. you could of course, always go into creative mode in a new world, but that only eliminates the level walling you'd get. The infinite grinding and the horridly lazy combat will still be prominent. Grind resources, craft items, build buildings, grind more resources, kill some mobs for their resources, rinse and repeat, maybe in a new order. There's nothing of substance until you've already poured so much of your time into it. But by the time you even get close to that point, will you really want to go any further? Even knowing there's going to be even more grinding and even more combat as a nessacary part of completing the main story (and I don't even know if it can be called a story, it all boils down to you hunting magical mcguffins with no readily apparent rhyme or reason)?

Final Verdict:
At around $8.00 normal price, it's not worth the money for most people looking for fun in a single-player, procedurally generated survival game. I got it dirt cheap during the winter sale, 75% off brought it down to 2 dollars and change, less than a cup of coffee. I think that price is more reflective of the game's merits. Those who are interested in teaming up with friends via the multiplayer may find some value, but even then, you could probably find much better experiences gaming with friends in other titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975018661', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 7151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6673, 'last_played': 1528981127}
review:
This is a tough one to give a 'yes' or 'no' to, because its right on the edge, I'll think about it while I write this review. 

Force of nature APPEARS open world sandbox, but it is so so SO linear, should you go into an area you haven't progressed to yet, you're going to be annihilated by super strong enemies, while if you go into a previously visited area (which you'll have to do frequently to grind for the gems needed to build certain items) you're going to annihilate all who stand in your path. Even the buildings and objects you can craft are limited by player level, so they have sort of doubled down on the linear progression locking. 

On the grinding, if you play this, prepare to grind! You'll clear an entire area out of enemies for gems, you'll save the game, quit, and load (which re-spawns the enemies) and grind again. I played through this ones at an early access stage, and then again once it was released. 

In early access, once you assemble the force of nature, it just gave a 'u win' message which was a little disappointing. Unfortunately, while more buildings, items, enemies, etc were added when I played it through after release, the ending was the same! A 'u win' message! 

Ok, so I think I'm going to say 'yes' to this because I did enjoy the time I sunk into it, though just be aware the game is about the journey, not the destination.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991704309', 'num_games_owned': 1038, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2349, 'last_played': 1546382238}
review:
First, the bad:
- Occasional crashes
- Collision-check prevention is kind've insane (i.e. certain hills you definitely should be able to run up, you can't -- you have to run around. Certain areas of trees you should be able to run between, you can't.)
- Run speed is pretty bad. Plan on making tons of teleporters
- Getting the next level costs resources... what?
... and some (type of, and quantity) of those resources are kind've rediculous.
- Chopping trees takes -forever- which means clearing a path through much of anything is just sheer painful and torturous
- You can't zoom in or out on the map
- Clipping plane is so pretty damn short and you can't adjust it either :/
- Development seems to have stopped?
- No swimming, despite lots of areas where there is water
- No jumping
- No terrain deformation, despite the ability to dig in the ground to get sand, soil, and clay

Now the good:
+ In depth crafting system (not quite as detailed as Wurm with temperatures of intermediary ingredients, and variations on existing recipees creating different items etc. but still decently in depth)
+ Framerates seem pretty good (though that could be because the clipping plane is so damn short)
+ Has multiplayer
+ Supports creation of a new world and saves (meaning multiple worlds -- 1 at a time)
+ Signs you create can have their text appear on the map
+ Portals show up on the map
+ Has a temperature system -- affected primarily (only?) by biome
+ Has day / night cycle

At present moment, I -could- recommend it if it weren't for the fact that development seems to have stopped. The latest news I see if something back in April (?) about trading cards. Really? Devs, you decide to refocus back on the game and dedicate time to it only to not work on the game itself, but use that time to implement trading cards?! My advice, presently, buy it on sale and use a trainer / cheat to make the game less tedious and annoying until the devs decide to start going to work again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044803765', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1546097280}
review: Boring. I really tried to give this game a chance. But, it is just too slow and clunky. Every action is unintuitive. Crafting and resource harvesting is tedious (even for a sandbox) and your leveling is tied to completing crafting quests. After you complete all the crafting quests,  in order to obtain the next level, you must hand in a certain amount of hard earned and painfully harvested resources. The combat is simplistic and I was never able to get traps to work propperly. I would toss them on animals and the animals would get trapped for exactly 1 second, I never had enough tiime to tame them. This mechanic seems broken or not well thought out. I never got a feeling of gratification or completion, I just felt relief that I had finally obtained another level, so that I could mindlessly follow the instructions (quest) and craft more stuff on demand in order to gain another level. I honestly, can't imagine playing this game for another second.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964353001', 'num_games_owned': 834, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1545912648}
review:
At this current state I cannot recommend this game.

It is a survival game (you start with nothing, you get guided with quests and you have to build your tools and your weapons to "finish" the game). Every labour task you do (getting ressources, fighting, etc.) uses up stamina which either generates slowly by itself over time or can be replenished by eating food (which at some point you seem to be able to produce yourself other than just farm what is there).

I consider it on the lower end of graphics.

Personally the stamina system feels forced. It's there to slow things down (which might be the intention, but I simply don't like it). So everything takes a lot longer than it could and it feels unnatural.
I am inclined to compare it with Graveyard Keeper (has the same issue) and with Minecraft (where "stamina" is not an issue, but hunger - however, that one doesn't really stop you from doing things at the same speed).

The inventory is clunky, the same is with the menu. Especially considering that things you craft on your person need to be taken out of the crafting menu into your puch (that does not happen automatically). And when you do so, and press the shortcut key, it always presents you with the menu to do more stuff (greying out the possibilty to grab the stuff you just made - its one more click only, but...annyoing IMHO).

You appear to lose your stuff when you die (as in -> its in your corpse which you need to find) and sometimes you lose stuff for real (seems as the corpse doesn't have all if it). With this I might be wrong, it happend to me twice, but I never really tried it several times (as I am trying NOT to die :)).
The possibilites to store stuff (especially at the start) are...limited...which I consider annoying.

Multiplayer works...however, awkwardly. If a player goes too far away, all other players are being beamed/transported to that player.
This makes multiyplayer very hard to play, at least in my opinion. 
The whole team levels the same (so not everyone needs to do their quests), so leveling up is easy when in a team (that might be considered a plus).

There wasn't an update for about 8 month. So I do guess it is considered finished.
However, it has a low price. So go ahead and try for yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198244715860', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1644, 'last_played': 1588786394}
review:
I like this game. Fun to play with another but,  I think it deserves another update. You could use players being able to split among the map. Maybe making the items cheaper to get becasue ther is quite a lot of grinding but. if you put on some music and talk with a freidnwhile playing this. the game is pretty good. Maybe make foxes Flee? and not attack you on site and kill you as a low level. Maybe make a boss for players to fight and maybe make the building a bit more customizable. The game has a lot of potential but, as a player you just think "it would be a good idea if you moved quicker or it would be easier to get coal." or even "I wish chopping trees wouldnt use energy, hell I wish using anything didn't make me lose energy." 

Definately worth a go though

author: {'steamid': '76561198063982645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 31528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31299, 'last_played': 1701420928}
review:
I have enjoyed this seemingly simple game a lot. I really liked the differend biomes as well as the increasing amount of building options when you have levelled up. But I must admit, the last levels can become boring. More options like sneaking, jumping and other special moves could juice this game up. On the other hand I fell for the dreamy casual atmosphere and somewhat simplistic gameplay of this game. But be warned, beating this game in hardcore mode is possible, but very, very, very far from easy.   

Thanks for the really good music, when entering a new biome.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969408588', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3083, 'last_played': 1546044158}
review:
So I've played it multiplayer now (just 2 of us)

I still think this game is slow, but its incredibly good value for the price!

It just makes you want to keep playing!


My Original Review after 3 hours solo play; -

Well it was fun, at first. But its slow, real slow. 

If your character could run, now that would help a lot!

Sure, I paid less than ¬£2 and it's totally worth that, BUT thats 3 hours of my life I'm not getting back!

In short: Avoid, unless you have an awful lot of time to kill and you enjoy tedium.
