author: {'steamid': '76561198104016942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 9132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5296, 'last_played': 1653835011}
review:
Got to say that I waited a while to get this game (mainly based on the negative reviews) but it became available at a special offer rate which was too low to refuse, so I bought it. 

Am I please I did. Loved it from start to finish. 

Ignore the negative comments that state you have to pick each and every item up singularly, becuase you don't, there is a multi gather button and it's not that hard to spot. I think the grind level is just about spot on compared with other games I have played in the genre. 

Again, ignore the negatives that state you have to grind, then wait, grind, then wait. It's all about time management, why craft something and then wait there until it's finished? Go and craft something else, or collect more resources whilst you wait, or go and beat up on a few Goblins. All good fun. 

If you're also going to run in to a battle with multiple enemies and have little to no protection, or sufficient Weapons, then yes, expect to die. That again is the same in most games I play. It is possible in this game to sneak up on and isolate single enemies. It's also easy to work out how to gain hits on enemies and not get hit back.This is where a good strategy comes in. 

To me, it seems that the negative reviews are simply from people who are used to having Weapons and Armour which means  you one hit every enemy and never get hit in return. This is where this game differs, good steady tactics win the day. 

Just finished my first run through and yes I will say the ending is a bit anti-climatic, however that said, I did achieve the objective that was stated right at the start of the game. A little more fanfare would have been nice. 

Overall, I'd give this game an 8 out of 10 and would recommend it to mates who have the guile and patience to play it. 

If you are after a "I want to run straight out into the big wide world and kill everything I meet without the need to craft a decent Weapon/Armour combo", then this game isn't for you. As the phrase goes, "Slow and steady wins the race".

Hier ist die Spielidee, das Konzept im ganzen einfach nur Stimmig und man vergist recht schnell das es hier eben keine High-End Grafik gibt.
Es macht Super Spa√ü die Welt zu entdecken die Anfangs vielleicht etwas einsam und unspektakul√§r wirkt.
Es macht Super Spa√ü den Charakter zu entwickeln - quasi nur aus dem was die Umgebung bietet etwas zu erschaffen.
Ich als jemand der seine ersten Games auf MS-Dos und Amigasystemen entdeckte, f√ºhlte mich hier sofort wie in der Zeit versetzt als Effekte noch nicht wichtig waren aber der Wiederspielwert und Features um so bedeutender. :) 

Ich habe zwar nur 3 Stunden Spielzeit auf der Uhr aber ich habe es vor dem Kauf bei anderen Leuten gesehen und intensiv angespielt - somit ist meine Spielzeit hier nicht wirklich von Bedeutung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025178442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1543670880}
review:
Not an RPG. Interface leaves a lot to be desired.

This game advertises itself as a mashup of survival/resource management/RPG genres, but it's a pretty run of the mill survival game. There's absolutely nothing customizable about your character, and the "quests" are essentially just there as gates to unlock higher recipes by crafting all the more basic items first. 

Everything about the menus and interface is fairly annoying. There are no shortcut keys for some of the menus (??) or actions, and often times you have to click a silly number of times or navigate in and back out of a menu to accomplish what you want. You can't actually click on anything in game to pick up or use unless you either open the inventory or hold spacebar, and while you have the inventory open your character can move but is locked facing one direction.

As far as the actual gameplay, it's decent but more tedious than other survival games I've played. Mining ore with the stone pickaxe is an extreme chore, you want to upgrade that ASAP. Low level animals do fairly heft damage even with the first armor set, and they never leave you alone. Farm animals stray a good distance from where you leave them and farming mats for fences is slow. The screen fuzziness at low HP is super unnecessary and annoying. The portals you can build make an extremely unpleasent sound (you can mute it which also mutes some other things, unfortunately),

Overall, it was fun for a few hours but eventually just got too annoying for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015623825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2727, 'last_played': 1517877819}
review:
What can I say, this game is just...FUN. Numerous crafting options to keep the crafter entertained and ever striving to get the uber recipes. I nice little time waster to pop in an out of just to do a little exploring or slaying or cooking or building. For a small title with a solo developer it is very very good.

If you're looking for ultra-hi res, 4k, 160fps quality game, then this is not for you. Look at a video before getting it and being super disappointed. For what this game was made with, the graphics are great and the game is great just from a playability factor. It is kinda retro with a modern twist I would say. I applaud the developer for sticking with it and sharing it with us...

author: {'steamid': '76561198080576142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 10694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3074, 'last_played': 1622757927}
review: Well up until now it's been fun, but now some crazy bug. I vanish itno mist land, all my animals are now dead but i'm left with piles of meat, eggs, feathers, milk, wool and leather etc. I can't figure out what's wrong, am i having this issue because i dropped to many things on the ground? They stay persistently in the world. I died, somewhere in the wilderness, do I have a stash out there to claim somewhere. Getting a little fed up having to restart catching animals again 3x now this has happened. This game has been out for a few years now, its not like its eary access, i thought it would be safe, seems i'm wrong, there is no support or anywhere I see to reach anyone. This is a very grindy game I don't mind that, but when you have to exit/reboot to get you stuff back inlcluding health this is an unplayable bug. Even at $bucks..don't waste money on this mess.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078226947', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3710, 'last_played': 1537728836}
review: Get ready for serious grind. Gameplay gets repetitive very quickly, you move slowly, fighting mechanics is dull and music just annoying. I thought FoN will shine at the end game, but I was mistaken. At the end it's just more grind with everything: with lvling, with crafting, with exploring and with building. Lore would be a strong plus for this game, if it has one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016380376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1541014897}
review:
J'ai achet√© ce jeu car je suis une grande fan des survivals et que je d√©teste la vue subjective √† la premi√®re personne. Don't Starve et Project Zomboid sont mes deux favoris et tous deux tr√®s bien faits.

Ce jeu en est loin :( le style graphique est la premi√®re chose qui m'a rebut√©e en commen√ßant. Aucune personnalit√©, de la 3D basique sans conviction, un seul personnage jouable avec quasiment aucune customisation (pouvoir changer le sexe, c'est quand m√™me la base, AVANT la couleur du slip -_-)
Ensuite l'interface m'a fait penser que j'√©tais tomb√©e sur un tr√®s vieux jeu - genre ann√©es 2000 - et je suis un peu tomb√©e des nues en voyant qu'il √©tait sorti en 2016. Aucune optimisation des menus qui sont tr√®s lourds et peu intuitifs, heureusement qu'il y a le tuto... on passe son temps √† ouvrir des menus partout... et tout est tr√®s moche, bon, pour l'interface, passe encore, mais l'ergonomie c'est quand m√™me un truc important bon sang... le reste du gameplay est mal fichu aussi.
Ensuite, de gros d√©fauts sautent aux yeux tr√®s rapidement, comme les comptes √† rebours de craft bien r√©barbatifs, le syst√®me de combat (quand on n'a pas de syst√®me de combat, on ne met pas les combats en jeu), les hitbox du d√©cor super foireuses...

J'y ai jou√© deux heures et j'ai coup√© en me disant que j'y reviendrai plus tard... ben j'ai pas envie du tout en fait. Je suis tr√®s d√©√ßue. Je vais plut√¥t retourner sur Curious Expedition.

review:
Entretenido, vale su precio.
Tiene gr√°ficos regulares, farmear el progreso es entretenido y no resulta cansador. Algunas mec√°nicas son toscas pero muy bueno en general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198444561117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 15904, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3652, 'last_played': 1696653926}
review: absolute dog wank this game is

author: {'steamid': '76561198079878190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1574113275}
review:
Do NOT waste your money on this game.  It is a frustrating mess.  There is a very specific progression chain that you MUST follow in order to level.  You do not accrue XP for gathering, crafting or combat.  Once you finish several quests, you get the opportunity to level, which requires more gathering/crafting/combat.

Graphics are crude and the camera angle doesn't help when you are trying to use a ranged weapon.

Crafting is at least interesting but time-consuming.  Best starter advice I read is upgrade your tools/weapons as soon as the upgrades are available.  And make sure your have lots of places to stash your items (a bit more on this later).

Taming is a joke.  Throw a net on a critter, press the space bar and click 'tame'.  That's it, done.  Also, each tame produces only one resource and you cannot tame combat pets, which would increase your survivability.  Tames also have to be fed to produces resources.

Combat (ranged and HTH) is awful and if you aggro more than one enemy you stand a good chance of dying, which then randomly removes items from your inventory.  Items that you have spent the last several hours gathering and/or crafting.  Items that you need to do anything, like survive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003791510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1541351868}
review: So far I like the game. I'm not quite sure why people are saying they are grinding and waiting, unless they have never crafted in other games. This game gives several tasks to complete while waiting for crafting items to complete. It's a somewhat simplistic game. I was looking for something like Minecraft with better graphics and I found it. I'm sure it doesn't measure up for Minecraft fans, but I'm enjoying wandering around gathering supplies and beating on goblins while building my homestead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041812857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 8044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1865, 'last_played': 1632568911}
review: I enjoyed this game.  I probably won't play it for much longer, and you have to have patience to get into it, but if you enjoy slow and emergent games, give this one a try if you can find it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064264373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1540584027}
review:
Gets old real quick. Leveling is nothing more than a grind, and needs some SERIOUS work. First, you have tasks to complete to gain a level . . fair enough. Those tasks involve getting resources, and building stuff. Cool thus far. Then you complete these tasks, after considerable grind, and get told to 'Gain a level'. THEN, you go to the character sheet, and low and behold you need resources as well to gain a level, often the same resources you JUST USED to complete tasks. WTF !! So then MORE grinding to get the resources. Its a game based on grinding, and waiting . . waiting and grinding.

Graphics are . . basic. 
Gameplay is slow (Dont believe the promo video . . a single hit on an enemy takes 3 seconds . . 3 agonising seconds)
Crafting is a grind
Leveling is a grind
NO story, or Lore
Zero reward for playing (The grind saps all that away)

I'd give it a 5 / 10 just for being . .

author: {'steamid': '76561198846419997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 990, 'last_played': 1619695182}
review:
The game theme is castaway or survival in a foreign land. I thought it will be like The Sims Castaway but this game offers more challenging quests.

I really enjoy playing this game. You can craft many things, raise your proficiency as you get to a new level, tame wild animal and make them your livestock, train your combat skill, and build your own home area. This game has a main quest to collect all fragments and craft them into the legendary fragment.

You also can play this game with your friend. That's fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975051410', 'num_games_owned': 1447, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1540391617}
review:
I have played a lot of survival games: some good, some bad.  This one was clearly, and from the start, a bland grindfest for the sake of grinding.  There was no hunger bar, no water bar yet it is marked "survival"?

After playing for 10 minutes I had 2 dozen bananas from kicking trees, and a backpack full or random crap.  They don't exactly make you work for your "survival".  I also managed to kill a rabit by kicking it in the head a few times lol

The crafting and building system had a little something going for it.  I could see that there was a little depth to that, but that is trumped by a not so great UI and dreadful control over your character/camera

I got this game for $4 and I am still going to get a refund.  Sorry devs, this game would have been good when the ps1 first came out, it just seems pointless when there is nothing driving your need for "survival"

author: {'steamid': '76561198077416022', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 1488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1448, 'last_played': 1554609467}
review:
Force of nature is a game that revolves around the system of grindage. now this is not bad for some people, but if you are an indivudiual who enjoys tending to multiple things at once, (eg. crops, livestock, inventory management) then you would like this game. 
The basic structure of the gameplay loop is... do quest,(either make structure or item to further your gear), collect items, find force of nature shard, use up tons of valuable healing and stamina products while achiving previous goal, then start building up supplies for next raid on force of nature shard. now this does not seem like that bad of a system but actually going from well to crops to each animal to cooking table and just trying to collect all the items needed to make something like a meat pie. its tedious to make sure to check on all of your resources like livestock, beehive, crops or the well constantly because they have a limit of how much they can hold and no one is there doing it when you are gone on a raid. and it takes to fun out of it when you need to take an hour to prepare all of your healing items for your next battle or the next time you find a force of nature shard.
When i heard of taming goblins i was hopeful of the thought of being able to tell them to do a task as simple as taking water from the well and bringing it to a barrel. but using them as nothing more than a meat shield in battle kinda made me sad. i wanted to see my village turn into a thriving town full of goblins hard at work, collecting wood, harvesting crops or tending to live stock. it really makes the game feel empty.

But its 9 dollars. and for nine dollars i believe that i got my money's worth.

I would love to see this game thrive and have updates that fix the issues that i have with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117589509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4157, 'last_played': 1539624970}
review: If you like to grind then stay away from this game. You have to LOVE to grind. They need to change the name to Grind of Nature because that is what you do 85% of of time. You grind then you grind again and then you grind some more. I figured if I just stuck to it it would speed up some...not true. The higher you go the more grinding you do. Did I mention that you grind a lot. Now that Im 63 hours in I have to finish which means I'll probably grind another 20 hours. UGH!!! I regret starting this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068986249', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1538699039}
review: Very good little game, good graphics, leveling system very interesting because you become able to make more and more sophisticated things. No real story, but simple to play. May be a bit grindy for some people, you have to little lie collect the materials. Construction of your camp is cool, you can farm and have animal. You even have a little ally with you, a captured goblin. :) For me it's cool and very pleasing! I recommande it, it's a 8,5 on 10 for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982898488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1538145522}
review:
Before I bought this game I looked at the gameplay images and it seems to look interesting so I bought it. Upon starting the game it immediately directs you to the main menu which I thought its odd since other games usually have other kinds of interlude screen before directing you to the main menu but that's really not the matter anyway since I'm still interested to try out this game. Once the game begun, seeing that my character woke up half naked on a beach so I thought that this must be where the survival aspect stars. As I play on, I find myself playing and waiting and playing and waiting which is really not what I wanted so I'm gonna start listing down the pros and cons of the game.

Pros:
1. Crafting system. The progress of the crafting system here is in % and you can craft different items from different objects like the bonfire.

I tried to think of more positive things about this game but there's just none I can come up with.

Cons:
1. Animation. The animation of the character does not look very lively. If anything it feels like I'm controlling a puppet.
2. Despite the genre says survival, I did not see any survival aspect here. There's no hunger, thirst, etc.
3. Game feels extremely grindy. Especially the leveling system. The concept of the leveling system is actually not that bad but because you're just grinding the same stuff you used to craft objects in order to level up, game feels extremely slow.
4. Combat. Combat in this game is very bad. You're basically trading damage with your enemies which means you got no way to dodge or block. You will get hit if you attack and that is the only way to attack the enemy. If you're up against multiple enemies, you're likely dead because there's no way to avoid damage.
5. The pace of the game feels extremely slow due to it being grindy.
6. You can't sprint also another reason why the game feels slow.
7. Confusing aesthetic environment. At first I actually thought that the world is just like our real life era until I see the goblin.
8. Picking up items in this game feels extremely tedious. You have to hold down spacebar and left click a particular item every single time to pick them up. 

All in all I just can't bear myself to continue playing this game. After I quit the game, I looked back at the gameplay images and what I see from that image is so much better than when I started playing the game. Yes I know that if I wanted to reach there, I need to continue playing the game but because the game feels boring I just can't. What I really wanted out of this game is just like the ones shown on the images but unfortunately it is way too grindy.

I'm giving this game 1/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089494190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 42408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2767, 'last_played': 1710202540}
review: If you love grindy games then this is the game for you!  I can spend hours in my settlement, crafting and farming which is rather fun for me.  But I love exploring on this game and opening up areas.  The leveling up system is different than I'm used to so that makes it unique to me.  Wish there had been a better tutorial though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068846818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1377, 'last_played': 1535480702}
review:
This game has so much potential, but limits you in every way possible. The gameplay is suuuuper slow, and you have to grind, grind, grind, grind and grind som more to even progress in the slightest. I'd love to help the dev out with ideas, because it has loads of potential to be a great game, but as of right now its just the same monsters, same combat, same items, same everything. 

I'm sad that it didn't live up to my expectations, because i had high hopes for it. If you enjoy slow progressing games, with clunky combat mechanics and a very boring world, then buy this game. I had fun for the first few hours, but it's too unpolished for me. 

Though, i have hopes that the devs next game might be really good, cause this is a good start with a solid foundation.

review:
Force of Nature ist ein tolles spiel. Und manchmal ist mir einfach Grafik lieber als dieses ganze High end zeugs.
Es macht spa√ü und gestalltet sich auch schwer, wenn es um die suche nach den bruchst√ºcken von Force of Nature geht.
Das monster desing finde ich genial. Und das man eben auch die m√∂glichkeit hat sich Hoftiere zu Z√§hmen.
Jedoch was etwas auf der strecke blieb, ist die Musik. Klar anfangs spielt eine sehr sch√∂ne melodie doch diese spielt nicht lange und dann ist es sehr still.W√ºrde mir sehr w√ºnschen das man noch ein paar passende melodien hinzuf√ºgen sollten.
Abschlie√üend ist zu sagen das spiel kann einen fesseln und es macht √ºbertrieben spa√ü. Der preis von 8‚Ç¨ is da auch voll ok.
Ich empfehle jeden spieler der nicht so gro√üen wert auf die "High end" Grafik legt dieses spiel den der effekt vom wasser ist so toll (*-*).
Bitte liebe entwickler macht weiter so!!

review: Muy recomendado, pero solamente en determinados casos, ya que es un juego tranquilo que requiere su paciencia, esta bueno para pasar el rato, dudo que alguno pueda jugarlo por muchas horas seguidas, si bien te pasas un largo tiempo cosechando, talando, minando, s√© que hay ciertas personas a las cuales les gusta (en parte) farmear, por lo que si eres de esas personas, combinado con el pve se vuelve un juego muy interesante que podes llegar a disfrutar mucho. Ni hablar si tenes con quien jugarlo, te aseguro que tener otra persona que le gusten este tipo de juegos es genial, no digo que no lo vayas a poder jugar solo, pero es mucho m√°s f√°cil y divertido con alguien m√°s. Sin m√°s, vale la pena. Espero les haya servido este peque√±o comentario.

A unique combination of a crafting/survival game and rpg-ish game.
This combination works pretty good.
If you enjoy games like Dungeon Siege and Ark, Rust, ... this might be a good game for you (and your friends).

author: {'steamid': '76561198191788177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1241, 'last_played': 1623270256}
review:
Okay, so this game comes with a warning and will only appeal the niche crowd that likes games you can idly play. It takes a long time, with a lot of fiddly things to do to progress with crafting things. 
Buuuuuuuuuuuuut if you like to watch youtube or netflix while you play games like I do, then this will do nicely! c:

About any computer could play this, I bet, so no worries there. Combat is a bit stiff but its a random-generating indie game, give it a break. Just get some snacks and coffee and chop away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198830210362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 935, 'last_played': 1593123170}
review: FoN is a game that takes some getting used to.   Lack of jumping, being able to look UP, and actual running, are the biggest cons to me.  With that being said, after playing for a bit, and getting used to the controls (Mass pick up IS there, just gotta look for it in the control menu), I am thoroughly enjoying this game.  It is a bit grindy, but its basically a survival game, so that is too be expected.  Farming, crafting, killing mobs.  I haven't progressed to end game yet, but thats because I like to take my time, and gather things I might need before wading into large groups of mobs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198305299533', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1676, 'last_played': 1548960104}
review:
This game has become synonymous with a giggle in my household, from the motion of the character with the stick to the yells of "c'mere ya little goblin gits, I only want your coins" (polite version) 

Most of us in this house own this survival game, it's simplistic but filled with fun, haven't managed to explore entire map as yet due to a reformat and a restart, must admit it's one of the clearest games to understand on how to play as you learn to go through the game.  Quests help immensely when chasing goblins for their coins, learning to craft bigger and better for yourself is part of it.  Ok it may be slow starter and grindy, with a low inventory but you can sort this as you grow in levels. 

Immensely enjoying this game and hope the devs continue to grow it to it's full capabilities over time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169443274', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2054, 'last_played': 1534540104}
review: The UI is a ittle confusing, but you get used to it with the help of Google. I also haven't sorted out the multiplayer (BETA) aspect, either. However, the graphics and sound are wonderful (forest ambience is shocking!), And I can play this on high graphics with a ten year old laptop. The amount of quality put into the game, even animal sounds, helps puzzle me why more people aren't playing just yet. If you like Minecrat, but without that annoying retro Lego look, this is for you. I certainly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198273026986', 'num_games_owned': 248, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 6339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6339, 'last_played': 1528471581}
review:
Um sobrevivente em uma ilha na qual devemos salvar nossas vidas. O jogo √© calmo e sem pressa, adequado para os f√£s do g√™nero(eu! XD). O jogo em si √© bem simples, nao tem muitos requisitos em graficos, mas sua jogabildiade √© oque tras a diferen√ßa, tera que sobreviver e ir atras de gemas do poder da natureza, no total sendo 6(Pelo que sei ap√≥s voc√™ onter as gemas, nao ira mudar nada no jogo), e cada local aonde elas est√£o tem monstros fortes (a cada parte de gma que pega os mosntros dos outros ficam ainda mais fortes) voc√™ tem que ter muita paciencia no jogo ate concluir suas consquistas e tamb√©m ter itens principalmente lascas de pedras preciosas, jogo parece sr pequeno, mas quando voc√™ entra na ilha √© enorme(Enorme mesmo), ent√£o tem muitos inimigos em cada local, varios biomas sobre a ilha, e seu unico objetivo √© sobreviver!
Diferente de outros modos de sobrevivencia, os monstros sempre da respawn a cada carregamento do mapa, sempre que matar eles e mudar de mapa ou usar teletransporte vai fazer uma tela de carregamento e quando voc√™ volta eles estar√£o la de novo(sendo dia ou noite).
Tem seu ciclo de dia e noite, com tempestades desde de chuvas ate de areias em locais de deserto!
O contra do jogo √© que voc√™ no inicio do game tera uma area bem favoravel e segura para construir, depois dessa area n√£o tem como voc√™ criar mais coisas, por conta que vao nascer mosntros e destruir, como ja disse e repito, o jogo tem a fun√ß√£o de voc√™ sobreviver ate colher os 6 elementos da naturza ou poder, com isso ap√≥s essa miss√£o concluir vai abrir um novo modo HARDCORE aonde voc√™ morrer perde o jogo e volta desde o inicio!! Mas vale a pena principalmente com amigos!!!

review: Very basic game play. I like the premise of it, it kind of has a story and a little bit of action. You can do basic building and crafting type things. But it's very basic gameplay and crafting depends on your level which makes it slow and limiting. Boring and repetative. Can't jump or crouch. Movement is slow. Just feels like a waste of time and effort.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120989263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3131, 'last_played': 1534192067}
review:
I originally had been looking at another game but the reviews werent great about the solo play so i looked through the related games and this one came up. It was only a fiver so I thought Id give it a go and 8 hours later Ive just come off for the day. It started slowly, but once you start getting the hang of it the levels are fairly simple. I began with the general game mode that went through a tutorial type of system. The only issue I had initially was the sensitivity of the mouse and after playing with the slider for a bit i eventually gave up and started to play the game. About half way through the tutorial I decided to have a look at the creative mode. This I found to be good as it gave you access to all the items in the sense of you didnt have to unlock them but you still had to collect the resources. This isnt a game for those who dont have patience. The graphics are ok but dont expect anything spectacular. My only problem is the way the screen goes when your health starts to decrease. As you loose more and more the screen becomes static like on an untuned television and it can mess with your eyes. Ive not had chance to try the multiplayer yet as no one I know has the game but Im hoping to have a go at that at some point.
Overall Im happy with the game and for the price is isnt bad, Ive played it for 8hours today and no doubt will be back on again tomorrow. One thing I would ask is that if any of the devs are reading this then could we have a female character please as only being able to play a bloke is rather boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198427780427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6530, 'last_played': 1534267233}
review:
[b]*Review written after 108 hours of gameplay - achievement percentage = 100%*[/b]
(Multiplayer Beta is omitted)

After 108 hours of gameplay, I leave this game with an strong aftertaste of incompletion and frowned eyebrows.

It starts with the shifting mechanics and the camera toggling: You can't jump or crouch. Why tho'? These mechanics exist in nearly every game. If the camera allows you a 360¬∞ horizontal view, the vertical view is restricted to 90¬∞. I mean, I can't see the sky. I can't even see the mill I build in its whole size. Why would the developpers do that?
Now to the game content - the main of this game is to collect shards of Force of Nature and to reassemble it to one piece. To come to this, you have to build your base level by level (there are 13 levels). That's it. There's no lore and in spite of the relatively big map, there are no secret places, buildings etc. or whatsoever to discover. Where does the Force of Nature comes from? Why do I have to reassemble it? Why do I start from a specific spot? Is there any background information about my character? Why are there hostile goblins and what not around you? What is their relation to all this? All these questions will not be answered and the ending (the reassembling of Force of Nature) will be rather disappointing. Why would you omit that? Why is there no lore? Basicly, you're wasting your frickin' time in trying to explore the whole map. And that's what I did: In fact, you can beat the game in 60-70 hours. 
Which brings me to my next point - for its mediocre content, you waste a lot of time (and money - 10 bucks in my case). And the most of this time goes into farming. It is a very intense farming game.  If you're not into that, don't buy this game. The only positive things in this game are the portals which allow you to teleport from one place to another, the hot key assignins which allow you to assign weapons and items like healing potions to a hot key and the concept of different bioms that forces you to adapt your gear. If these mechanics would not be present, the game would be really unpleasant. 

However, the negative things don't stop there: The building menu is too restrictive. If I could chose between this game or Minecraft - it would be clearly Minecraft. Furthermore, the stamina consumption in this game is ridiculuous. It needs a "trillion" years to refill completly and if you use items to refill it, you need a ton of them. I can't tell you how many coffee cups I used in my entire gameplay to refill constantly my stamina bar. 
The maximum level you can reach is 13. You enemies will be from level 1 to 20 and higher. Why though? Never attract a bunch of them or you're dead. Btw - dying 10 times doesn't make you a bad player even if there's a Steam achievement for that. You just have bad luck or the game is cheatin'. Last but not least: The map has dark spots - steep places you can't reach. If it doesn't have any purpose - why do you integrate it in the game? 
 
If you are a minimalist, this game is for you. If not, don't buy it. 
As a man who plays games mostly for lore and more ambitious mechanics, I can't recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013671801', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4094, 'last_played': 1563200593}
review:
I have enjoyed the game. It [b]IS[/b] grindy but if you plan to kill some time, slowly build yourself a place to call home and wander around chopping down trees, shoving a pick deep down a rock and slaying monsters and beasts alike then this is a solid game. You're encouraged to tame animals, protect them and interact with them in order to advance through the game. You also get to plant your own stuff and even decorate your surrounding as you wish. The fighting mechanics are not really so bad, you quickly get used to them and easily manage to kill anything. 

There are lots of things to craft and build, so there's a long gameplay to be enjoyed and lots of option to explore, I have played sixty hours so far and I have found myself surprised a few times. The objective in the game is somewhat unclear, which makes me believe there'll be one or two things more for me to see.

The singleplayer mode is where I've spent most my time and thus to which I refer in the paragraphs above. The Multiplayer maybe needs some cleaning and shining but it is in beta state so there's not much to complain about. I'd complain about the fact that if any of the other players die, everyone dies, which is strange and perhaps, stupid. 

Not to prolongue myself much more, I would give the game a 7.5 out of 10 and add that most negative reviews I have seen from this game are unfair. This game is nice and sure can be fun to be played with friends or with your family.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970617782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 1590, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1188, 'last_played': 1624214643}
review:
A deceiving little gem.

This game is "yet another survival game". (I personally love those, they're my favorite. If you don't, take that into consideration.)

This game, however, is *far more linear* in nature, although it opens up in subtle ways. You are given quests to accomplish. "Craft a stone axe." "Craft a stone pickaxe." Etc. When you knock of a few quests, you get the next step in the progression. It takes a while before it's more generalized, like, "Build [a crafting station of some kind]". It's at this point where the game expects you to realize you may need more of a certain metal to make a certain other crafting element or station before you can make the final goal.

In this way, the game is highly structured, always giving you a goal. At the same time, you do reach a point where your creative beast is unleashed. How much effort you choose to put into creating a base, and decorating it, and doing all the necessary work is up to you. The game will never say, "Make you base protected by a pallisade, lay down sett (paving) and line it with street lights". You have to choose to do so. Will you? That depends.... 

This game is "grindy", in terms of traditional crafting games. You will constantly need to go out, cut down trees, mine, hunt monsters, harvest, craft, etc. to keep your supplies up. The things you start at first- creating some burning hot embers- is something you will continue to do, as you add more to your plate. More embers, more coal, more water from the well, more farming, more cooking.... you will have a list of tasks you run around your base every minute topping off. 

Do you have to? No, unless you are in dire need of that thing. But part of the fun is getting ahead of the curve. It's great fun when you finish a batch of 100 "cups" of coffee, and know you're not going ot be out of energy anytime soon- but it's rewarding because you did a decent amount of work, and waited for the crafting to finish, for that coffee. On the other hand, as you use it, you'll be thinking, "Do I really need this? I'm gonna need to craft another huge batch soon, and that'll take a while." In other words, your resources are valuable.

The combat is fine, nothing amazing, but it works. There is challenge, mostly in the form of getting overhwelming by 4-5 mobs at once, so you have to pull some critters with your bow and use the terrain to funnel them toward you sometimes. Other times you can just walk around killing lower level things without much worry. There's always progression, where difficult scenarios will become easy in time due to progress.

For less than $10 or so, last I checked, you will get at least 60-80 hours, if not several hundred.

It's a very, very high quality game that is fun. A bit chill, a bit meditative and lonely, but also goal oriented. If you enjoy survival games, pick this up. And do me a favor, don't get disturbed by the DO X quest method. You will have plenty of creative freedom while accomplishing your quests.

Great game, super glad I grabbed it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085504066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3408, 'last_played': 1532125591}
review:
Kia ora!

If you like building, crafting, farming, managing, fighting monsters and collecting loot then I suggest you have a look at this. The graphics are beautiful and there is plenty to do to keep you busy for many hours. Unfortunetaly this game also has some flaws, which could potentially ruin the experience for some players.

PROS:

- Beautiful world with day and night cycle. The graphics are not high end but more than enough for such a game! Flora and fauna look very pretty. A lot of fun just to walk around, explore and kick bananas and apples from the trees.
- Lots of different items to craft, mine, gather and catch including wood and stone, ores, food, weapons, clothing, plants, animals and more.
- RPG elements. You will be fighting a lot of monsters, level up your health and stamina and craft weapons.
- Although only a beta at the moment, there is a simple multiplayer co-op option for up to 4 players.

CONS:

- The controls, camera and UI could be better. Takes a bit of time to get used to.
- Overall the gameplay is a bit slow and feels linear. Less resources for structures would help to keep the game flow better. Gathering wood and ores can feel like a chore.
- There are some poor game design choices that seem odd and can be annoying, such as the walking speed, breathing under water, catching animals (did the developers try this?) or limiting players to a certain number of structures in story mode.

Overall still an enjoyable game. Played over 40 hours solo and now trying the multiplayer mode.

review:

Yorum yapan arkada≈ülara bakƒ±yorum oynadƒ±klarƒ± saatler ile oyunu anlamalarƒ± ger√ßekten √ßok zor biraz √∂nyargƒ±lƒ± davranmƒ±≈ülar.

Quest sistemi ve combat sistemi sizi bir≈üeyler √ºretmeye ve sava≈ümaya mecbur bƒ±rakƒ±yor. Yakƒ±n bir arkada≈üƒ±nƒ±zla keyifle 50-60 saatinizi ge√ßirebileceƒüiniz bir oyun. 

Tek eksi yanƒ± son seviyeye gelmenize raƒümen 5-6 adet su kuyusundan √ßift√ßilik ve hayvancƒ±lƒ±k i√ßin yeterli suyu edinemiyor olu≈üunuz hepsi o kadar.

5,75 TL iken almƒ±≈ütƒ±m oyunun g√∂z√ºmde ederi en az 20-30 lira indirimde ka√ßƒ±rmamanƒ±zƒ± tavsiye eder, iyi oyunlar dilerim.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986805907', 'num_games_owned': 1982, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1531401187}
review:
This is not a good game. It's the skeleton of a perfectly decent game, but the development seems to be on hiatus. So whether its many issues will ever be resolved is anybody's guess. As it stands in its current state, it's not a good game, and you should stay away.

The core issue is time. Everything takes a long time, and mechanical skill at the game doesn't make it any faster. It's just designed to take a long time. Gathering is slow, crafting is slow, combat is slow, healing is slow, regaining stamina is slow... Even using the interface is slow thanks to bad UI design that requires multiple clicks to accomplish frequent tasks.

Even setting aside the slowness of the game, one of the many questionable design decisions in Force of Nature is its linearity. It's a survival-crafting game that isn't a sandbox. That's not necessarily bad, but the way FoN does it is simply used to make progress take arbitrarily longer. The things you can craft are not only limited by your available resources, they're also gated by levels. The initial stone mace, the first available proper weapon, guarantees that you're going to get hit about half a dozen times in every single combat. That means that each fight requires at least a minute of slowly consuming healing items and watching your health slowly refill, and lord help you if you aggro two enemies at once. (Three enemies is a guaranteed death.) And because better weapons are gated behind levels, you'll be using that initial stone mace for at least an hour, maybe more. You're compelled to use it until you're allowed access to better weapons. You'll also be naked for a long time, because clothing and armor are comparatively deep in the progression.

I've never actually gotten past the stone mace. In order to level, you have to obtain specific items and complete specific quests. The quests are nothing to write home about, but the items quickly become terrible. Specifically, to advance beyond the level where you first obtain the stone mace, you need to collect a certain number of gold coins and a certain number of copper coins.

Those coins are dropped by goblins, which are by far the least dangerous enemies on the island. So far, so good. The problem is that goblins are dramatically outnumbered by animal enemies. Animals don't drop coins, do far more damage than goblins, and love to run away before you can kill them, virtually guaranteeing that you'll get nothing for fighting them. The next problem is that there are two kinds of goblins, and only the rarer kind has a reasonable chance of dropping copper coins. In both my attempts at playing this game, I have spent well over an hour wandering the island looking for copper coins, all the while having to chew my way through unproductive fights with animals who mostly just cost healing items without any reward. And then, both times, I wound up aggroing something far too powerful (which will happen when enemies have levels that you can't see until they're already chewing on you), and finding that the game had decided to change the rules on me - instead of being able to run away until it dropped aggro, it kept chasing me for ten minutes of slow loops around a section of the island, very slowly biting down my health just barely faster than I could slowly eat healing items. So I died.

The death penalty in FoN is straightforward: you permanently lose a random selection of things from your inventory. Not that big a deal, really. Until one of the things you lose is nearly all of the copper coins you just spent over an hour beating your head against.

So yeah. With further development and reworking of certain mechanics, FoN could be quite enjoyable. It's the skeleton of a decent game. But right now, it's quite bad. Stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021625231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 2606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2512, 'last_played': 1543217222}
review:
The final teir armor looks like a hobo shirt, with plastic gold bars glued onto it... This game has the ugliest armor and char model in the history of gaming.





=FORCE OF NATURE- aka- taking a dump= When nature calls yo!

This is one of those games I seen on steam for a long time, in my maybe pile... finally I decided to bite when the sale price was low enough... Why a maybe? It looked kinda janke from the promo video, pretty low production value. But every now n then, you buy a game like this that looks pretty janke n stanke, but then has this magical gameplay, such as empyrion. You never know where a gem can turn up!
After playing for 40+ hours, and finally beat the game I gotta say---


It's no gem, or even "survival", but it is still a pretty fun game.




========SLOOOOOOOOOOW MOTION=========

Indeed as expected, as I expect from all good janke games... it started very slow... REALLY SLOWLY... You move about as fast as a turtle, and your stamina drains to 0 after cutting down just a few trees... Most negative reviews seem to be about this, and that's a shame. It's still more then playable! If you stick with it, it gets a little better.
I personally like slow weak characters at the start of any game that features progression. I don't want to start out super strong with nothing to work towards. However, you never do get moving very fast unless you pave the world in roads, which you probably won't care or need to do. 

Another problem with speed is how overgrown the world is, no matter what biome you are in. You have to hack your way through the thick vegetation to get around which is fun at first, but gets old later on. You and the monsters can't just squeeze through trees and brush even though visually there might appear to be enough space... so techically all the monsters are actually trapped in the world, and you are rescuing them so you can slay them for the precious gem shard drops. 
The landscape is pretty bad too, and your char can't jump, or even slide down slopes, a slight incline can stop you from moving forward. Yep... The ugly terrain random gen ensures you will constantly find hills that impeede your movement.

Cutting down trees, and bushes is also slow, with a slow animation, and quick drain of your stamina... The player char ends up being the ultimate coffee junkie, as you will need to slam down hundreds\thousands of coffee to get through this game.

Your view distance is turok 1 level of fog... You cannot see very far, and there is no option to change this. So expect to take a bad path through zones, and have to backtrack to find a better route to where you are going.

All of that contributes to what is a pretty slow moving experience in the game.... 


====EXPLORATION====

You only go to new biomes to farm the next force of nature shard (need them all to win the game, and level up), and to get new gem chips which are also needed to level up. You might also go there for the next type of rose you'll need to mass farm later perhaps, and to find more minerals to mine. But for the most part exploration isn't that big a feature here. The world is so overgrown and open fields so rare, the exploration honestly is pretty bad. There is no special places, or ruins, or loot to find, just generic overgrown wilderness. OH LOOK A HUGE GOLEM!!>.. oh it just drops stone\1ore\gemchip?... \yawn...

There is various biomes, but it all ends up being the same experience. And the same 3-4 types of mobs that can appear in any given biome are spammed every so far in spacing from one another. It's pretty repetitive and lazy. Scorpions.... everywhere...

To even explore most biomes you have to sacrifice the GOOD ARMOR you'd like to wear, to instead have to wear tempurature resist gear, hot and cold sets.
SO WHY EVEN HAVE ARMOR FOCUSED GEAR!?
You know it's bad when they have to make a ridiculously named "amulet of comfort". So either you sacrifice wearing armor with good protection, or amulets with good stats.




COMBAT---

The combat is as barebones basic as you can about get, and is so janke you can even exploit a glitch. Swap melee weapons to interupt the swing animation to effectively double your dps!

Bows exist, but using metal arrows is too expensive to bother with, so most of the game you'll just use burning stone arrows. In real life-  arrows are retrievable- especially metal ones.


CRAFTING---

The game might have exploration and combat but crafting is the real heart and soul of this one. You will do a LOT of it. Sadly most of that crafting is the micromanage type.
It starts out fun but by later game you will be sick of the fact that wells fill over time to hold so little max water, only 6...
How tedious it is, to collect the 6 water, every other minute- which in this world is not very much water.

Then to collect\replant the crops which yes... fully grow in only about 2 minutes
then to collect the mushrooms that yes, fully grow in 2 minutes
water and feed the animals every 2 minutes (not required but they only make eggs\milk if you feed them)
then roses which fully grow in about 3-4
then the coal is done about every 15 minutes
the burning embers (who holds those in their backpack in real life lol?) every 30 minutes
then manage your crafting tables of other types, workbench\altar\alchemy\tailor\stove

What you get is the most busy work I've seen in a crafting game in a very long time...
Which is really fun at first... indeed the first 20 hours I had fun doing it, but this ends up being 90% of your played time in the game sadly. The game definitely needed a way to upgrade all your constructions, so a well can hold 50 water, crops should take MUUUUUCH longer to grow, but have more at harvest time, same with animals, and everything really... More automation, less tedium clicks, and just make it take longer!

nope...
All this busy work is there to hide the fact that the combat and exploration sides of the game are extremely lacking. It's the only way the game can keep you busy for long. 

You can craft an epic city, with defensive walls... but mobs only attack you if they happen to wander into them... what's the point then? Unless you build in a dangerous biome, but why would you? What benefit is there? The game doesn't give a reason to build an epic base. Just build the various craft stations and call it a day.



=====CONCLUSIONS OF JANKE=====

I liked this game far more then other crafting games like stardew, or starbound *anything named star really lol*.

The game ended up being way more fun then it deserves to be. Despite all my points against it, I had a pretty good time with a friend, even though the multiplayer is pretty badly done. You can't go far from each other, AND the hideous long loading times you have to deal with when travelling about 300 meters in any direction. See? I can't help it, so much is wrong here... But it was still a pretty good time! It was fun to live and work in a world together and achieve every new structure and level up. Even bad crafting survival games often end up fun. A testement to this genre being better then most others imo. 



===EARLY ACCESS===
The engine is so bad I don't expect the dev can work miracles with this game, and I do not expect it to grow much with time. He will probably just add a few more biomes of the same repeating gameplay, a new craft station or 2, and call it a day. It's not like he can completely revamp the graphics, ai, and other broad systems... doing so would pretty much call for just starting over and making FORCE OF NATURE 2: FORCIER!


===SHOULD YOU BUY IT OR NOT?===
Recommended to crafting fans, who like a slow down to earth feel, and are not afraid of a little grind. A unique take on crafting, at the expense of pure unadulterated janke... The problems are worth enduring.

review: Definitely, Force of Nature is for patient players. As for me, I quite enjoy the grindy aspect of the game. I don't like the music though but you can always turn it off. You need to get used to key controls which might take some time. The gameplay is flawless - it doesn't lag or crash. The world is pretty big and diversified. You need to take into account and calculate many factors. A great challenge for smart mature men in mid-life crisis.

author: {'steamid': '76561198175130595', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1796, 'last_played': 1531162684}
review:
I'm a bit torn on whether to recommend this game because it all depends whether or not you like true painfully grindy games.  

Each world as far as I can tell, is like Minecraft, it generates a new randomated world for each new game started, placing different things in different places different spaces away from the player.  Great, I thught, unpredictability and different world each time could be interesting exploration wise.  

However...

If you think this is going to be like minecraft, think again.  

So you start the game stranded on a beach with nothing as a male with no clothes except a pair of trousers.  You have to gather materials to build things.  The minute you start gathering, your stamina goes down and regenerates slowly, so you're in a constant bind to find food.  You unlock certain crafting stations, great...but some things take a minute to make one food ingredient  (like minecraft's furnaces).  If you have to make a food item with several ingredients this is painfully slow as guess what?  They CAP how many things you can have at once.  I'm level 8, I can two have two food stations.  I need Butter and and Flour...they take AGES to craft.  It takes me an hour to get enough of the two ingredients I need to make one thing that won't get me very far either.

Your levels are capped until you pass certain requiremnts and quests like "find a force of nature", an element that can be at one end of the bloody map too far to get to.  You spend three hours getting enough materials and food together to make the journey a quarter of the way which takes maybe half an hour to forty five mins depending (as you'll spend more time trying to find a way through badly designed terrain or cutting your way through forest which are blocking the path).  You can spend nights and nights just getting half the way to one level.  You do less hunting,exploring and gathering resources outside of your base.  What do you spend 95% of the time doing?  FARMING, because you need those farm resources to crafft the food to survive the wilderness.  Unfortunately three hours of constant crafting can get you about half an hour's worth of adventuring, which is a pain in the bloody backside.  Everything hits much harder than you do.  You're level 8, a bear is level 3, bear is wrecking you in three or four hits you're nearly half dead.  Foxes and boars constantly attack you, and OH FUN, they effing run away when their health gets low and they run WAY faster than you and the bow and arrow are rubbish (they can't fire up hill for example)  so you can't even kill them.  You get no experience for the trouble either.

I think the worst part is really that they cap everything.  You need tons of water to feed the animals AND to water crops you need - you need tons of crops to make one small food item, but you can only have a few wells so it's a case of feed animals, or water crops, make food and survive past the farm.  You can't do both most of the time.  Even with three wells, it's particularly hard when a cow takes two buckets of water a time but your farm takes one bucket per seed - you get three wells at lvl 8, so that's 12 buckets.  You have six chickens that ned a bucket each, two cows that need two each, etc...they make it far too hard to truly feel free and enjoy the farm or building anything,   You have to get higher up in level to unlock the right to build another item or farm, etc, which just really stunts being able to freely build and have fun.  I've played nearly 30 hurs, my character is level 8 and can't get any further because the map is so poorly designed, rivers i can't cross, hills that can't be climbed or descended, it's just bad design entirely.

If you want a game that you'll spend weeks grinding in a farm for a couple of hours of adventuring, go for it.  If you want a game that you do a lot of other things beside farming, get Conan or Ark.  Or get this on sale, play for a day, then hang it up because it's too repetitious.  I'm done, I don't have the energy for this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033577891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3502, 'last_played': 1535270554}
review:
This game had a lot of promise.

TLDR:
The early game's building and crafting is fun and engaging
The combat is very mediocre
The end game turns combat into a frusturating grind.
The game could benefit from way more building options, including more cosmetic options. 
[spoiler] The payoff for all the work you put into the Force of Nature is quite disapointing.[/spoiler]

I liked the building at first. You start off with basic tools, basic huts etc. The progression feels good at the start. I was fine with the limited amount you could build at the start because there was the expectation that the cool stuff would be unlocked the end. However the end game just does not reward you with enough payoff in the customization you can unlock. 

As for the base functionality, I like that you can queue up crafting in your base at every workstation. 

The focus on the game is the Force of Nature. As such, you will be after Force of Nature Shards for the majority of the game. This will force you into the wilderness, where you will be fighting in a combat system that gets stale quickly. It essentially consists of spamming the attack button and your food hotkey to heal. After the first two areas, the combat for me felt like a chore to get to what I really wanted to do: build. 

And then there was the Force of Nature itself.
[spoiler] For all of the work and grinding it takes to construct this artifact, I would expect it to do something cool.
It took:
7 Forces of nature 
4500-4000 Roses
16,000-18,000 Water for each of the roses 
2250 Sand
4500 Glowing Embers (1500 sticks)
225 Coins
930 logs

And yet there was zero payoff. It did not do anything cool like I would expect. You can place it if you want. It looks alright. But otherwise it's only interaction is to be consumed to level you from level 12 to level 13. I was fully disapointed.
[/spoiler]

Perhaps I was expecting too much out of the game. However the game could have done better in many areas. The game is fun for what it is. I suggest playing in creative mode to bypass the tedium and get straight into the game's limited strength: the base building. 
If base building was added to the end game, Force of Nature would have been a much more satisfying game. It is a shame because in my opinion, the base interactions was it's strongest point. 

I had fun with the game. And it was SO close to being a more satisfying game. But it just misses the mark on so many points, and this saddens me. 

It's fun enough for something to do if you buy it during a sale, but in my opinion there are much better games for both the combat and the building.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005357441', 'num_games_owned': 1911, 'num_reviews': 248, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1530863985}
review:
I love this sort of game, but I have to give this one a no. 

-Stamina system is annoying. Not enough stam food, at least in the first 4 hours. Takes so much stamina to do anything you have to eat at all times. The net gain from chopping trees makes this a constant problem.

-Tool progression is too slow. 4 hours in everything is still a pain in the ass.

-Level system preventing me from building whatever I want in whatever quantity I want means this is NOT a sandbox game. Its very linear. 

-Combat is forced, boring and clunky. Early on there is no way to stop a running enemy until the bad path finding does it for you. Not enjoyable. 

-Game doesn't like to alt-tab. Every graphic change requires a relaunch. Exit from main menu likes to crash. 


I liked the lootables laying everywhere. Graphics were ok. General concept needs work, but overall it was a good start. Maybe my map gen just sucked, but all the metals I needed were hard to find making everything stupid boring.

The hardest achievement I earned was dying. With no armor I literally pulled 5 mobs and had to just stand there... for like a minute.

author: {'steamid': '76561198175740649', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3058, 'last_played': 1596666721}
review:
A momento de jugarlo son 27hrs de juego y mas menos puedo opinar:

¬ørecomienzo este juego? solo a cierto perfil, si eres de esos que disfrutan con la exploracion de supervivencia, si eres de aquellos que aman la construccion primitiva y que buscan ese seudo-realismo: ES TU JUEGO.

Graficamente no es perfecto pero se juega fluido que da gusto, tiene sus parones MUY puntuales pero no es nada que da√±e o merme la experiencia.

El combate es; mediocre, es tosco y poco practico aunque es a doc, agradececia que a posterior a√±adieran, bastones, lanzas, ballestas y javalinas le daria al juego un aire mas primitivo. El uso del arco esta bien me falta profundisar su uso para decir si esta bien o no pero desde ya comento que puede ser perfeccionado. Solo que si agregan el chanse de recuperar municion o partes de este se llevaria el 10.

Los recursos, hay que entender en que si hay cuevas en todos lados como bien pasa en Minecraft generaria un uso de recursos enorme, Donde si brilla la ausencia es en que los recursos como manzanas, cocos, platanos, ramas, troncos o hojas de palmera; NO SON RENOVABLES, si la mecanica de juego fuera lenta aceptaria ese hecho pero hay recursos que son acelerados como la comida asi que este factor puede ayudar el incorporar la forma de renovar recursos como arboles, arbustos y que elementos como las palmeras o manzanos puedan regenerar frutas o recursos adicionales siendo el manzano un elemento fundamental en unas mecanicas.

La exploracion es comoda no le veo mayores problemas o defectos, el uso de portales es muy a acertado facilitado el traslado.

Mis mayores quejas serian:
-el uso de adoquines da mucha velocidad de movimiento si la reducen sentaria mucho mejor.
-la obtencion de oro es a mediano plazo FACIL, es saber grindear y tendras mucho oro. Puede evitarse reduciendo el drop de este y a√±adiendo recursos como puede ser pepitas de hierro, cuero, carne, cuerda o semillas del bioma

donde pueden mejorar:
-a√±adir bastones, lanzas, javalinas, ballestas y ondas al arsenal.
-en las armas de municion esta pueda recuperarse o parte de estas en un chanse.
-funciones a las capturas como puede ser que las cabras puedan transportar algunos elementos o los goblins que atrapas sean un burrito de carga.
-poderle a√±adir funciones al goblin como puede ser recojer agua, plantar puede dar mucho juego pero lo dejo mas como una fantacia que como un elemento que pueda ser mejorado.

Sin mas que a la aventura que este juego es MUY bueno que me tiene enviciado y mi mas grande felicitaciones a los desarrolladores por esta obra mi mas grande satisfaccion con este titulo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047361974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 3239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2740, 'last_played': 1611813619}
review:
How can you go wrong? Many games charge far more and offer far less.
Easier as multiplayer as in faster but still not fast. 
Single player is a struggle as you'll need to progress more slowly.
Hard enough to be a challenge but not so hard as to require you to "git good".
Beautiful graphics and colors and the random gen map always seems to look good.
Combat is simplistic and a bit clunky but still offers nice options like knives, clubs, various arrows etc.

Simply put it's a little gem of a game and if for some reason you don't like it then heck, it's cheaper than a pack of gum.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996224551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1530523771}
review: Force of Nature has a lot of good aspects and a lot of bad aspects that overshadow the good. First you will notice a majority of the reviews say the game is slow. The game isnt slow, the game feels slow because it is poorly designed. Force of nature uses a leveling system which is implimented to be more of a tutorial of sorts in which content is locked behind levels. This would be fine if you didnt have to make literally every new unlocked item in a level to progress to the next level. This makes the game feel boring because there is no free choice, you feel like you are just checking off boxes on a never ending list. It takes far too long to get to the good part of the game to make the game worth purchasing and even if you hit the good part you feel no pride because you got to that point because the game forced you to that point through a disgustingly poorly designed leveling system. Which brings me to the reason Im giving the game a bad review the tags are wrong. There are no survival aspects no food meter, no water and no danger. You basically spawn in and start the game in a whole foods. At best it is a really mediocre game to kill sometime with a buddy in the games VERY beta multiplayer and at worst it is a grindy slog that rewards you with no sense of accomplishment for doing anything because the game beats you over the head with its god awful progession system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254642701', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1008, 'last_played': 1623512256}
review: I've only been playing for a couple hours but i'm totally hooked. the game is grindy, at first but in a really relaxing way where you can multitask. I think the controls are semi unique and pretty great, the game is pretty and i already have the urge to play this together with someone else so i'm going to get a couple copies. However in my opinion the trailer and video's on the game's steam store page don't do it justice. This game is better then i had expected and i am probably going to sink allot more hours into it. I regret postponing my purchase of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055207201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 607, 'last_played': 1533299336}
review:
GREAT! Hidden gem of a game.  Highly recommended for single player or even better for COOP with the friend or girlfriend. Deep crafting mechanic. Chill play style. after 2.4 hours i am starting to get that nice feeling like the area where i settled is becoming my home. 

I bought it at 66% off for about $2.90 and feel like im ripping the developer off. Im going to encourage the dev to do some DLC and will happily pay full price for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017781105', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1530173492}
review: By the time of this review I haven't been playing that much. Despite that I really dig this game. It has a lot of potential. The map looks a bit broken but what to expect of a game in early access. On the plus side there's a great beginner questline to help you getting started and the game itself looks great and runs smoothly! The crafting menu is easy to learn and the grinding isn't bad at all. Overall it's a game worth more than the pricetag and I can't wait to see what future updates will bring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052598774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1368, 'last_played': 1530021981}
review:
I gave this game a lot more time than I would have normally, since I received it as a gift from a friend.  I could see a lot of potential in it, and really really wanted to like it. 
The game plays a lot like an early access/early beta game unfortunately (and indeed, I've played some early access titles that were significantly smoother than this one). The UI and controls are very clunky and a lot of the gameplay just isn't as smooth/optimal as it could be.
However the incredible time sinks and grindy feeling just wore me down. Waiting 20+ real minutes between doing things in the game, just waiting for your stamina to regen was frustrating. Especially when that full stamina bar, only let you chop down 2-3 trees which might give you enough logs to make enough coal, to make 2-3 bars of metal to make 1 item which is a component then for something else. 
Then there's the fact that upon death you lose literally hours and hours of time worth of items that you made (even just simple food takes an incredible amount of time to make in this game) and how much you lose goes up with each death. Oh, by the way there's no way to tell a mobs level before it attacks you either, so death isn't uncommon. 

So for those TLDR: It's a very pretty game, that would have had a lot of promise, but it just feels like an abandoned early access title that was never finished. Not even worth the sale price for the frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198259534706', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 6364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1706662865}
review: I just bought the game because it was on sale, otherwise I wouldn't have found it. But i'm sure glad I did because it's well worth the full price or even more. In my full experience of gaming, I do enjoy playing mmorpgs and mostly moba/pvp type games but there's just something about this game that already has me hooked. Alot of tryhards out here might complain and leave bad reviews because it just doesn't suit their blown-out ego and crafting takes "too damn long" but in my opinion it's what sets it apart from most games. I haven't played much yet just a few hours as of now but I don't see myself quitting anytime soon.. With that being said, congrats Devs on building this unique game and I look forward to seeing more and better content in the future. +1

review: Only game I have ever refunded on Steam. The controls are extremely clunky and the menus are unituitive. Gameplay is slow and non-engaging and crafting/gathering resources is tedious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198297692277', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 832, 'last_played': 1651294955}
review: This was sort of an impulse buy; however, I am thoroughly impressed with everything this game has to offer.  The graphics are wonderful, the idea is brilliant, and I found myself having fun in a very short amount of time.  My poor boyfriend has trouble pulling me away to play other games with him.  There is a splendid sense of accomplishment each time I advance or complete something that shows progress toward something amazing.  I'll be glad when more is added.  I'm eager to see how it will grow.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes to explore a new world; the calm and soothing experience of staying home and tending gardens and animals; and, of course, those who like to battle monsters and mean critters who want to eat your face.  It is a fantastic game.  So glad I spent the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098444256', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3067, 'last_played': 1545087187}
review:
PLEASE READ: Many reviewers are saying they do not like the controls because it is tedious picking up things. I thought this too and almost stopped playing until I heard my husband's voice in my mind "Check the control settings." There is not a tutorial that explains this but in the control setting you will see there are quick harvest and quick pick up options. The game was much more enjoyable after I discovered this. 
I absolutely love this game. Think ARK meets Diablo II. Two of my favorite games in one.
I have been slowly enjoying the game and not working extremely hard on completeing the quests quickly.  I have over 47 hours in this game and unfortunately this means I am running into issues with save space. I cannot port to a new area without the game shutting down. I am on my last quest and excited to complete it, but I cannot possibly because I am stuck at my Home Base Location. Please help? I really want to finish this game but it keeps crashing...

author: {'steamid': '76561198047540254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1529773878}
review:
The mechanics for collecting items/resources Is very strange. You have to press a key (default is space) to allow the character to pick up items, and then press another (default is L mouse button) to collect that item. "Creative Mode/Sandbox" isn't a true creative mode, you still lose health, stamina, and you still have to collect resources, which is very slow. I bought the game for the world exploration and to mess around in the sandbox, which in this game just isn't my cup of tea. The biggest draw away for me though is the two button system for collecting. I just can't get used to it and so probably won't get far in the game. I'm not sure how I would go about altering the controls for this, as no matter what I'd need two buttons since that is how the game is programmed. 

Others have said that playing in multiplayer is good/better. I haven't tried that mode so I can't comment on it. However with the current pace of the game, it most likely is better in a co-op situation and would help it move along faster. 

Note: I bought this game during a sale for 2.95.

review: I have really enjoyed this game. The style of it reminds me of old school runescape. It is a very grindy game, though enjoyable if that's what you like. review: I appreciate that this is a game that children can play.  It trains them to think logically, solve problems, and be prepared for the unexpected.  The violence is minimal and is not graphic.  I've enjoyed watching the children play.  I also enjoy this game myself!

author: {'steamid': '76561198218568356', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 4528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4528, 'last_played': 1525040628}
review:
Enjoyed it at first, but getting the ressources becomes more and more tedious and annoying.
Especially the randomness of particular drops is annoying, but also that you can't really isolate enemies, which sometimes results in you shooting at one enemy and thereby aggroing the 3 enemies within a 10m radius as well. So instead of fighting 1 enemy, you fight 4. And die.
Some day I might play this game again, or I might not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159807450', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 249, 'last_played': 1528837800}
review:
Un juego que requiere tiempo, no es recomendado para los jugadores casuals de los Survivals. No tiene los mejores graficos del mundo, pero sus graficos no se hacen pesados. Una manera muy distinta a los otros Survivals de grafteo y recojer items.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030308926', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1545707991}
review: Amazing game. Basically Force of Nature is a slow based survival game. It has alot of adventurous areas to explore and fight monsters. For $8 you will be getting alot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105633837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 872, 'last_played': 1528862039}
review:
This is a great game.  Yes, the pace is sloooooow and if you are trying to rush through everything without reading the instructions given by the game, you will find movement, crafting and just about everything else a royal pain.  Slow your roll, don't try to hurry through the game and you will find it enjoyable.

Couple things of note:  Get the best weapon you can early. Get armor made. Get a fishing pole and fish. Have something constantly crafting because crafting takes forever.  Don't venture out further than your quests have you venture... or do and enjoy some death.

(Note to Devs:  You could speed up crafting time by about 25% because at times it is painfully slow and I can see that aspect ruining the game for people with less patience)

TLDR: Relaxing grinder with fun exploration albeit some clunkiness in learning to navigate and interact (15 minutes is all it takes to get used to it... really), entertaining fight experiences and logical crafting. Not for the impatient or those who are expecting epicness.
